Eksod (Albanian for exodus) tells a story of a movement of people that seek an escape from their unfulfilled lives. Eksod delivers this story through an experiential exhibit using live performance, sound design, and photography to depict an Albanian's struggle to emigrate to a different country at any cost. 






The Significance
Eksod is a reduction of architectural acoustics, filmmaking, sound design, and photography. I have emphasized combining these fields because they are my historical foci, and because innovation has a track record of occurring when cross-disciplinary fields merge.


Justin installing "Peacock Farm" in Brooklyn, NY 2015
To date, I've installed in cafes and art expositions. Eksod will be the first presentation of a narrative story in a purposefully designed acoustical environment as it was originally perceived to be executed. 
I moved from the United States to Albania in an attempt to realize this dream and began pre-production in January of 2016. I need your help. 


 


What's Needed & What You Get
This Indiegogo campaign is required to fund the production costs associated with capturing the mixed media story in Tirana, Albania. No funds are being asked for gear. This campaign is not allocated for the printing and physical construction costs of the exhibit. Grants and sponsorship have been earmarked for the post-production stage and are outside the scope of this campaign.
The production costs that your contributions will fund are as follows:  Rental car costs on 6 shooting days - $350
Food for the supporting cast and crew on 6 shoot days - $600
Cost for access/permission to shoot at locations (A Butcher Shop and an Albanian Home) -$200
Additional baggage cost to transport camera, lighting, and sound gear round trip from NYC to Albania - $350
Production Office for 3 months - $900
Production and fullfillment costs of perks - $450
Wardrobe designer on 3 shoot days - $450 
As a thank you, artwork will be provided to contributing supporters - details provided in the "Perks" section.



 



Impact of your Donation
Installment of Eksod represents more than a completed artwork. I left behind my commercial sound recording business in the states that had been my means of meeting my cost of living.  Eksod is a gateway from the technical to the creative stage of my career. It's my aim to create exhibits like Eksod on behalf of organizations, other collaborating artists, and small businesses that value and need to express in sensory immersive ways. By supporting this project, you are giving me the traction I need to transform a career, you are bringing attention to a struggle facing a beautiful Balkan region, and you are acquiring artwork for your personal collection.



Challenges
Organizing this project in a foreign country comes with a range of obstacles. Yet the pre-production task of finding a local cast, crew, location, and accommodation have all been resolved as of the start of February of 2016. I've managed to escort a sound, camera, and lighting kit capable of meeting this projects needs into Albania. All the pieces are in place and I would like to begin shooting in March. The last puzzle piece to overcome is the financing that will allow production to commence. 




Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't in a position to support, but know someone that would have interest in this project please let them know.
If you are interested in seeing Eksod installed in a city near you, and if you're familiar with an arts organization/venue that may be a good fit, send along your ideas.

story:
the project: personal connections and broad significance

I'm an artist and lifelong resident of the American south. Growing up in the pine belt of southern Mississippi, longleaf pine were dominant across the land leaving deep imprints on my identity. More recently, the view camera provided a way to reconnect, to attempt having regular and authentic connections to what little remains of this incredible landscape.  As I dug into the natural, cultural and economic histories of the this tree and its fire dependent ecosystem, it became a search to see what was still there and what it looks like today. 

Prior to the onset of European settlement in America, the longleaf pine was the keystone species in a landscape mosaic that covered some 90 million acres of southern Coastal Plain from Virginia to east Texas. In the late 19th and early 20th century original longleaf pinelands were all but wiped away by human action at an industrial scale.
This body of images,The Pines, explores remnants of old-growth longleaf pinelands across the southeast United States. Historically, this was once one of America's most significant landscapes.

At its climax, it is maintained with frequent, non-fatal fire, and it is also an extraordinary bio diverse ecosystem rivaling that of the tropical rain forests. 

These images are my experience in the present that give a tiny glimpse of insight into both past and future. More than only a concern for creating visual records or an archive of yet another shortsighted American decline scenario, I am interested in the complexity of human presence, natural beauty, and environmental change in this decidedly southern, contemporary post-wilderness landscape. These images are a meditation on this landscape’s significant past and present and consider how loss and beauty can coexist to motivate a better future.

The images were made over the past seven years, majority shot with an 8x10" view camera, some 4x5" and 6x7 as well. The large format film was drum scanned and many of the images have been produced as large scale prints and exhibited in regional art museums and non-profit centers over the past few years.  

the book

Publishing a book of my photographs has been a creative goal of mine for many years, and I'm most excited to work with Daylight Books to publish my first monograph. Please consider supporting the production and printing of this photobook, your contributions will help this project get into the world.

The Pines: Southern Forests 

  • trim size: 10 x 12 1/2 inches
  • 112 pages
  • features 63 color plates 
  • printed on high quality 150gsm Artic Volume White paper
  • hard cover is fine textured paper over board 
  • edition of 1000
  • preface by Chuck Hemard
  • essay by Rebecca Barlow, Alabama Cooperative Extension System Specialist and Associate Professor, Auburn University School of Forestry and Wildlife Sciences
  • poem by Nick Norwood, professor of creative writing at Columbus State University and the director of the Carson McCullers Center for Writers and Musicians in Columbus, Georgia and Nyack, New York

The book is set to be shipped mid to late Fall 2017, with official release of the title from Daylight sometime in early 2018.  Indiegogo backers should expect their copies sometime around November 2017! Of course I'll update backers with news of any delays in the process that would effect these arrival dates.

your support

It is my hope that with your generous support, this book will help the images and what they represent find a larger and wider audience. Pine trees are quite common across the south and beyond. While based in the region, this incredible landscape's story should be better known, so I hope the work can find an expanded audience both within and beyond the region. 

Within the region, this book adds a creative voice to the ongoing conversations about longleaf ecosystem restoration. I hope it can spread awareness of the inherent cultural and aesthetic value, and inspire us collectively to look further than only economic drive of short rotation tree farming that has become the norm in the region. Even in the Deep South most people seem unaware of how their landscape has undergone significant change, and it is my hope this book might shed some light on what might be regained, and even ask us to reconsider the notion of progress.

the break down

My funding goal is set to $8000 which will help offset a portion of the design, production and printing costs of this book.  Daylight Books is an incredible team to work with, and they will oversee the design and editing as well as printing and distribution.  I'm thrilled to be included in their catalog of finely produced books with engaging content.  

While contributions of any size are most welcome, I am offering both pre-sales of the book and also offer limited edition versions that come with an exhibition quality print in addition to a signed copy of the book.  Additionally, I'm offering a few exhibition quality prints at a range of sizes including the large scale, limited edition prints from this body of work.  

All the proceeds from these perks and rewards will go to support the production and printing of 1000 copies of the book.

This campaign is set as a flexible goal, so even if we don't quite reach the goal, all funds will still to toward the book and all perks or rewards will still be sent to you.  I hope you'll help me make this campaign successful and meet or even exceed the goal!

the perks

If you choose a perk or reward that includes a print, at each different size there are image choices. You will select this after you click on the perk, but below are illustrations of the images you can choose between at each size.  The larger size prints all ship securely rolled in a tube.

Below are the 3 image choices for the 6x8" Special Edition Print or the Limited Ed. of Book w/ 6x8" Print 

 

 

Below are the 3 image choices for the 16 x20" Limited Edition Print:

 

Below are the 2 image choices for the 26x32" Limited Edition Exhibition Print:

Below are the 2 image choices for the 34x42" Limited Edition Exhibition Print:

 

the photographer

Born in New Orleans, raised in south Mississippi, studied in Georgia and now living in Alabama where he teaches photography at Auburn University, Chuck Hemard is a lifelong resident of the American south. His recent photographs, made mostly with large format cameras, explore the complexities of contemporary landscape. In 2014, he was awarded an Artist Fellowship from the Alabama State Council on the Arts and has work included in public collections across the southeast United States, including the Columbus Museum of Art in Columbus GA, The Georgia Museum of Art in Athens, GA, and the Ogden Museum of Southern Art in New Orleans.  He recently became a Certified Prescribed Burn Manager in the state of Alabama.

Any help at any level is much appreciated!  You can also help by sharing this campaign via your social media and using the Indiegogo share tools.  ... and again THANK YOU!

story:
Emil Busch was a pioneer of modern-day photography. In fact, he was the first to design and produce remarkable anastigmatic lenses – lenses that correct for spherical aberration – actually some time before other famous manufacturers such as Zeiss with whom he worked closely. 

In 1865, some 25 years before Dr. Paul Rudolph introduced his Protar lens to Zeiss, Busch patented the Pantoskop lens, the world’s first true anastigmatic lens.

 

© Mirène Schmitz

 

Prototype of our new Glaukar F3.1 (97mm)

 

It was an excellent wide angle lens and his experience with this anastigmatic lens construction inspired the later development of the famous Glaukar.

In 1910, Emil Busch introduced the Glaukar, a fully corrected photographic lens, which besides solving spherical aberration, corrected coma and astigmatism was a "usable" lens. Unlike Rudolph’s Protar, which did not work properly at the time of invention because its construction required glass coatings not available at the time, the Emil Busch Glaukar lens was the first anastigmatic lens for daily portrait photography.

By creating his anastigmatic lenses, Busch corrected the above mentioned faults by careful combination of the lens elements. Sharpness and artistic images were possible for the first time.

In its time, the remarkable and usable anastigmatic lens Emil Busch’s F 3.1 Glaukar Anastigmat, was considered a very “fast” lens, meaning it worked well in available, low-light light.  

 

The Glaukar created a very special portrait-effect. The Glaukar was a lens that was specifically used for portrait-photography since it was fast enough to come to a more natural design of the image. It was characterized by the homogenous transfer from sharpness to the more fuzzy areas. Very important: the chromatical aberration was extremely low for the time. 

To bring back the legendary Glaukar lens it is necessary to fully reinvent the Glaukar from scratch for modern photographers and their state of the art equipment.

Prototype of our new Glaukar 3.1 (97mm)

 

And now:

Also available in Modern Black or Profi White

Our Emil Busch Glaukar 3.1 in two new color options

The brand new historically-inspired Glaukar lens gives you an opportunity to create the type of image quality and feel of the early days of photography on modern equipment. 

 

But even though the inside of the lens is state of the art technology, we have succeeded in keeping the modern version true to its legacy by not only maintaining the characteristic image quality but also replicating the Glaukar’s distinctive historic look.

Portrait lenses of this time were using the typical plate camera format of 8cm x 10cm or 13cm x 18cm. Recalculating this to modern time lenses of 24mm x 36mm, the reinvented 97mm / f 3.1 Glaukar is equivalent to the original 3.1 / 210 of the 1910 Busch lens so it becomes a modern time lens with a focal length of 97mm.

The new Glaukar will have the same brass appearance and silhouette as the original but will, in fact, be high-end aluminum with a brass-like oxidation, which ensures the durability and mechanical precision of a modern lens. Furthermore we believe that the look and feel of a lens is also part of the fun of using it.

Expected delivery date of the lens is August 2018. 

Historical Emil Busch Glaukar F3.1 Anastigmat from 1910 (left)

vs.

the reengineered NEW Glaukar (right)

 

The Emil Busch Glaukar portrait lens is not a copy of an old lens but in its reinvented form is a state of the art lens. It uses the same classic three-lens-design of the original Glaukar lens.

 

But due to its specially coated lenses, it produces a fascinating mixture of sharpness, strong colors and, along with 15 aperture blades, wonderful bokeh effects. Since the original Glaukar lens was used on the “Plattenkameras” of their time, its successor had to be reinvented from scratch. It was a very difficult job that took us much longer than expected but now we are very proud of the result.

It was critical to create the perfect portrait lens. The shift from focus to fuzziness in the background needed to be just right. At open aperture the lens must liberate the subject from the background and with a closed aperture the image must have an even sharpness. At the same time the skin ton must be most natural to avoid or reduce the necessity of post production as much as possible. All these features are reborn in the reinvented Glaukar.

© Mirène Schmitz

The Emil Busch Glaukar Anastigmat was a breakthrough in its time and we have brought its abilities into modern times. In the early 20s of the last century, Busch himself, described the Glaukar as a lens systems with 

“the remarkable adaptability to so many classes of photographic work, [that] entitles it to rank as one of the most important additions made in recent years to the apparatus of the scientific and amateur worker. 
The aperture F/3.l is so large as to enable pictures to be taken even in the most unfavorable lighting conditions, and offers the photographer the means of securing mementos of theatrical or other performances and ceremonies indoors, and all photographic work, either interior or exterior, where lighting conditions require an exceptionally large aperture lens. 
The lens is especially suitable for all work, including Portraiture, Colour Photography, Reproduction and Enlarging.” 

 We do not have much to add to this very fitting description, which is still valid today. (source: Busch, Projection and Enlarging lenses, London, year unknown)

© Mirène Schmitz

© Mirène Schmitz

© Mirène Schmitz

 

Emil Busch was the son of the Berlin businessman Ludwig Friedrich Busch and his wife Jeanette, who was the daughter of the optical entrepreneur Johann August Heinrich Duncker who had founded his optical company in 1801.

This company passed on to Heinrich’s son, Eduard. Eventually, Emil Busch took over after his uncle’s death in 1845. Busch quickly introduced new ways of production, invested into machinery and started to develop cameras. In 1865, he introduced the first anastigmatic lens, the wide angle Pantoskop.

He worked closely with Zeiss and, actually, one of the Zeiss sons – Roderich – worked as an intern with the Busch company. Zeiss and Busch formed a cartel and controlled the optical industry in their day.

Emil Busch was clearly the founder of the modern camera and lens manufacturing, especially of the principle of anastigmatic lenses that could actually be used in daily photography with the kind of glass available at the time.

Not only have we recreated one of the most famous lenses of all times. In fact, this lens is especially suitable for videography with people as the main subject.

The Nikon version of the lens can also be ordered with a Fuji G mount adapter and be used on the mirrorless Fuji medium format camera system. 

  • Focal length – 97mm 
  • Maximum aperture – 1:3.1 
  • Aperture range – 1:22 
  • Image circle – 43mm 
  • Field of view – 25° 
  • Electronic contacts – none
  • Closest focussing distance – 1,5 m 
  • Lens construction – 3/3 
  • Filter thread – 52 mm 
  • Max diameter – length 73mm/80mm (DSLR), approx. 85mm mirrorless 
  • Weight – 410 g

 

MTF Glaukar f3.1

 

  • Nikon F
  • Canon EF
  • Pentax K
  • Sony E
  • Fuji X
  • MFT
  • Leica M

Help us to bring the old world into modern times It was hard work to get to where we are now but we want to share this with you. With your support we can set up and start production. The lens is certainly not a mass product and the quantities will remain small in comparison to the large manufacturers of today. 

This lens will practically be handmade piece by piece in the future. Therefore and due to the amount of manual work that has to be done it will sell for a retail price of approximately $2.000 USD, strictly online to avoid all overhead costs. 

In this Indiegogo project, we offer you great deals which will never be seen again. So by supporting us on Indiegogo you get an unbelievable deal on this lens. 

The creative minds behind Emil Busch are Benedikt Ernst and Firat Bagdu. Benedikt, born 1972, and Firat, born 1973, are renowned photographers with a speciality in portrait, wedding and fashion photography. Both have a broad education in arts and business management and combine creativity and managerial abilities needed in such a project. The two photographers always wanted to create just the perfect lens for their work and went searching for historic masterpieces. 

Their customers include famous individuals as well as companies like Chopard, Rolls Royce or Redken to name a few.

Benedikt and Firat defined the principles and joined with lens designers and manufacturers in Germany to design the first prototype. We are working together with manufacturers and consultants with a long experience in the optical industry.

So in other words we are a start-up but we assured ourselves of years of experience.  “We have seen some campaigns in the past were “old” lenses were brought back to the users of today’s cameras and appreciated them, but we wanted to go further and recreate a lens that would otherwise be lost”, says Firat. "But at the same time the quality of the lens must be to highest standards as well", adds Benedikt Ernst. Therefore the founders are very glad that they could ensure the cooperation with some leading german firms. Manufacturing will be done mostly by Uwe Weller Feinwerktechnik in Wetzlar, Germany. The glasses employed will be Schott and Ohara. 

We are very happy to have ensure the relationship with Uwe Weller GmbH since the high precision elements of the lens require fulfilment of very tight standards of production. Uwe Weller GmbH is the result of the merging of several firms including the mechanical devision of Leica Camera and Zeiss-Heusoldt into this competent manufacturer.

By exclusively using Schott and Ohara glasses we make sure that our ideas of creating the perfect portrait lens are met.

Special thanks to Mirène Schmitz, Tamara Skudies and Raffaele Horstmann who supported us in our project.

The new Glaukar will ship internationally from Germany starting in the summer of 2018. We charge 20$ for deliveries to the US and inside EU. Shipment to Countries outside US & EU will be charged with 50$.

Please note there may be extra import costs/customs/taxes to pay upon delivery, depending on your location. Customs and taxes are subject to possible change and applicable law at the time of delivery will have to be taken into account. If you have a question about shipping or handling, please don’t hesitate to contact us! 

For backers inside the European Union: Please be aware that VAT is not included and has to be added (19% German VAT). After this campaign ends, we will come back to you regarding the VAT.

  • The Use of Historic Lenses In Contemporary Photography by Paul Lipscombe (Book available for purchase on iTunes)
  • A History of the Photographic Lens by Rudolf Kingslake 
  • https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rathenower_Optische_Werke – gives you background and the history of this firm (but unfortunately its in German)

 

We are going to work with companies that have a lot of experience in the production of photographic equipment.

We have already been in touch with several possible production facilities who produce for leading manufacturers. But we have to be realistic in terms of the challenges on the way that we might have to face. We have a first prototype but it is always a challenge to go into serial production. This includes several steps and along the way problems might arise. We are sure we will solve all of them but it is hard to forecast them and the time needed to solve them. The new historic Emil Busch lens will be a lens of high quality and modern state of the art lens technology. So we will put quality above everything else which might lead to a slowdown of the production process. All our expected delivery dates are estimates only. Be assured that we will work very hard to get this beautiful lens into your hands as soon as possible.

All these features are reborn in the reinvented Glaukar.© Mirène SchmitzThe Emil Busch Glaukar Anastigmat was a breakthrough in its time and we have brought its abilities into modern times. In the early 20s of the last century, Busch himself, described the Glaukar as a lens systems with “the remarkable adaptability to so many classes of photographic work, [that] entitles it to rank as one of the most important additions made in recent years to the apparatus of the scientific and amateur worker. The aperture F/3.l is so large as to enable pictures to be taken even in the most unfavorable lighting conditions, and offers the photographer the means of securing mementos of theatrical or other performances and ceremonies indoors, and all photographic work, either interior or exterior, where lighting conditions require an exceptionally large aperture lens. The lens is especially suitable for all work, including Portraiture, Colour Photography, Reproduction and Enlarging.”  We do not have much to add to this very fitting description, which is still valid today. (source: Busch, Projection and Enlarging lenses, London, year unknown)© Mirène Schmitz© Mirène Schmitz© Mirène Schmitz Emil Busch was the son of the Berlin businessman Ludwig Friedrich Busch and his wife Jeanette, who was the daughter of the optical entrepreneur Johann August Heinrich Duncker who had founded his optical company in 1801.This company passed on to Heinrich’s son, Eduard. Eventually, Emil Busch took over after his uncle’s death in 1845. Busch quickly introduced new ways of production, invested into machinery and started to develop cameras. In 1865, he introduced the first anastigmatic lens, the wide angle Pantoskop.He worked closely with Zeiss and, actually, one of the Zeiss sons – Roderich – worked as an intern with the Busch company. Zeiss and Busch formed a cartel and controlled the optical industry in their day.Emil Busch was clearly the founder of the modern camera and lens manufacturing, especially of the principle of anastigmatic lenses that could actually be used in daily photography with the kind of glass available at the time.Not only have we recreated one of the most famous lenses of all times. In fact, this lens is especially suitable for videography with people as the main subject.The Nikon version of the lens can also be ordered with a Fuji G mount adapter and be used on the mirrorless Fuji medium format camera system. 

Focal length – 97mm 


Maximum aperture – 1:3.1 


Aperture range – 1:22 

Image circle – 43mm 


Field of view – 25° 

Electronic contacts – none

Closest focussing distance – 1,5 m 

Lens construction – 3/3 


Filter thread – 52 mm 


Max diameter – length 73mm/80mm (DSLR), approx. 85mm mirrorless 


Weight – 410 g
 MTF Glaukar f3.1 
Nikon F
Canon EF
Pentax K
Sony E
Fuji X
MFT
Leica M
Help us to bring the old world into modern times It was hard work to get to where we are now but we want to share this with you. With your support we can set up and start production. The lens is certainly not a mass product and the quantities will remain small in comparison to the large manufacturers of today. This lens will practically be handmade piece by piece in the future. Therefore and due to the amount of manual work that has to be done it will sell for a retail price of approximately $2.000 USD, strictly online to avoid all overhead costs. In this Indiegogo project, we offer you great deals which will never be seen again. So by supporting us on Indiegogo you get an unbelievable deal on this lens. The creative minds behind Emil Busch are Benedikt Ernst and Firat Bagdu. Benedikt, born 1972, and Firat, born 1973, are renowned photographers with a speciality in portrait, wedding and fashion photography. Both have a broad education in arts and business management and combine creativity and managerial abilities needed in such a project. The two photographers always wanted to create just the perfect lens for their work and went searching for historic masterpieces. Their customers include famous individuals as well as companies like Chopard, Rolls Royce or Redken to name a few.Benedikt and Firat defined the principles and joined with lens designers and manufacturers in Germany to design the first prototype. We are working together with manufacturers and consultants with a long experience in the optical industry.So in other words we are a start-up but we assured ourselves of years of experience.  “We have seen some campaigns in the past were “old” lenses were brought back to the users of today’s cameras and appreciated them, but we wanted to go further and recreate a lens that would otherwise be lost”, says Firat. "But at the same time the quality of the lens must be to highest standards as well", adds Benedikt Ernst. Therefore the founders are very glad that they could ensure the cooperation with some leading german firms. Manufacturing will be done mostly by Uwe Weller Feinwerktechnik in Wetzlar, Germany. The glasses employed will be Schott and Ohara. We are very happy to have ensure the relationship with Uwe Weller GmbH since the high precision elements of the lens require fulfilment of very tight standards of production. Uwe Weller GmbH is the result of the merging of several firms including the mechanical devision of Leica Camera and Zeiss-Heusoldt into this competent manufacturer.By exclusively using Schott and Ohara glasses we make sure that our ideas of creating the perfect portrait lens are met.Special thanks to Mirène Schmitz, Tamara Skudies and Raffaele Horstmann who supported us in our project.The new Glaukar will ship internationally from Germany starting in the summer of 2018. We charge 20$ for deliveries to the US and inside EU. Shipment to Countries outside US & EU will be charged with 50$.Please note there may be extra import costs/customs/taxes to pay upon delivery, depending on your location. Customs and taxes are subject to possible change and applicable law at the time of delivery will have to be taken into account. If you have a question about shipping or handling, please don’t hesitate to contact us! For backers inside the European Union: Please be aware that VAT is not included and has to be added (19% German VAT). After this campaign ends, we will come back to you regarding the VAT.
The Use of Historic Lenses In Contemporary Photography by Paul Lipscombe (Book available for purchase on iTunes)
A History of the Photographic Lens by Rudolf Kingslake 

https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rathenower_Optische_Werke – gives you background and the history of this firm (but unfortunately its in German)
 We are going to work with companies that have a lot of experience in the production of photographic equipment.We have already been in touch with several possible production facilities who produce for leading manufacturers. But we have to be realistic in terms of the challenges on the way that we might have to face. We have a first prototype but it is always a challenge to go into serial production. This includes several steps and along the way problems might arise. We are sure we will solve all of them but it is hard to forecast them and the time needed to solve them. The new historic Emil Busch lens will be a lens of high quality and modern state of the art lens technology. So we will put quality above everything else which might lead to a slowdown of the production process. All our expected delivery dates are estimates only. Be assured that we will work very hard to get this beautiful lens into your hands as soon as possible.

story:
"Dance is the movement of the universe concentrated in an individual."

- Isadora Duncan-

The Dancer's Facade: Dancing Through A Pandemic 

Thank you for visiting my crowdfunding page which I'm running to help finance my new photography based project, The Dancer's Facade. 

My name is Manuel Meza. I am a dancer, choreographer, and photographer currently living in Essen Germany while I finish my MA studies at the Folkwang Universität der Künste. During this global pandemic, I have become inspired by the perseverance of the dancing body and the adaptations the dancing world has undergone. Through the limitations of this pandemic, many found their individual movement. The Dancer's Facade is a photographic interview between myself and the dancer's I come across. 

The Book

The Dancer's Facade: Dancing Through A Pandemic will focus on the journey of 10-15 dance professionals during the Covid-19 pandemic; allowing them to get in front of the camera and tell their stories through movement. Focusing on photographs, the book will also incorporate written text taken from oral interviews of each participant. The photographs will give the viewer access to the intimate and imaginative lives of the dancers; photographing them in their flats, public spaces, nature, empty theatres, and hopefully in empty museums. I see this book as a way to document this intense immobility we face juxtaposed against the simplistic beauty of movement. 

Goals of this campaign

The purpose of this Indiegogo campaign:

  • Payment fee for each dancer involved 
  • Payment for the graphic designer
  • Publishing costs so this book can be seen by a wider audience 

You can help achieve my goals by: 

  • buying from the list of products (perks) shown on the right hand side of this page

  • or clicking on the pink "BACK IT" button (at the top right hand side of the page) to donate

  • or a combination of the two.

The Impact

This project will give the dancers a chance to tell their personal experiences of this pandemic through movement and oral interviews. At the same time, it will give the audience an opportunity to reflect on their own immobile reality and their desire to move. Each individual in this project will be able to express their frustration, sadness, and hopefulness through their movement; while I document their journey through photographs. In order to heal we must create. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge will be to raise enough money to pay each dancer a respectable payment. I believe it is extremely important that I am able to offer some sort of compensation to the individuals who will be working with me on this project

Spreading the word

Reaching people and connecting with them is the hard bit of any campaign, so: 

If you know others to whom this may appeal, please tell or share this page with them by email or on social media.  Your connections could really help make this successful.

 

Thank you so much for your time and support, it is greatly appreciated.

Documenting University in the age of Corona

story:
Way Out - Volume I

Concise, clean & crisp. A year's work, broken out into four sections - each featuring a season, and each page following a color palette.

About Nathan

Nathan Peterson is a self-taught photographer based in Montana, USA.

Growing up in Montana provoked an active lifestyle, so most of Nathan's free time was spent on the slopes in the winter and on trails in the summer. Due to a deep fascination of space, he began photography at the age of fifteen in order to get a deeper look at the night sky. Naturally, these hobbies met and developed a passion for 3am trail breaks, twelve-hour drives & a taste for gas station snacks.

Nathan's biggest inspiration lies within the mountains of Northwest Montana, specifically Glacier National Park. Glacier has served as his stomping ground for the last three years - tallying up over thirty trips in that time. With that, Peterson seeks to find new perspectives & views on every trip, while creating awareness of mankind's impact on earth and encouraging preservation through photography.

The Book

Way Out is the culmination of a year (almost exclusively weekends) spent on the road, photographing the Western United States & Europe. With the primary focus being mood and color, it is divided by season.

Winter

Spring

​Summer

Fall

What You Can Give & What You Can Get

Interested in purchasing a copy? Check out the tiers & packages in more detail below:

All orders will be finalized and placed at the end of July - backers can expect to receive all deliverables by mid-August. 

Perks

[Early Bird] Way Out Softcover

Act fast! The first ten people to back the softcover edition receive a 20% discount on a signed copy of Way Out. 

 

Way Out Softcover

Backers will receive a signed copy of the softcover edition of Way Out. 

 

[Early Bird] Way Out Hardcover

...gets the worm? Be one of the first ten to pre-order the signed hardcover edition of Way Out, and receive a 20% discount. 

 

Way Out Hardcover

Choose this perk, and receive a signed copy of the hardcover edition of Way Out. 

 

Way Out Softcover + Print

Now we're cooking with gas! Elect this option and receive the softcover and a signed 8 x 10 print from the book. Find the print options below! 

 

Way Out Hardcover + Print

Same as above, just a little bulkier. Scroll down for a choice of ten prints. 

 

Grand Slam

Almost as cool as an all inclusive vacation. Receive a signed hardcover copy of Way Out, a signed 24 x 36 canvas print from the book, and a signed 8 x 10 print from the book. Scroll to the bottom for canvas and print options. 

Oh yeah, and FREE SHIPPING!

Limited to four backers. 

 

Full Send

The Sultan of Swat of Indiegogo perks (did this just turn into a baseball book?).

Be one of two people in the world to receive a Layflat Limited Edition of Way Out, featuring 6 bonus pages. Not only that, but you'll receive a signed 24 x 36 canvas print, TWO signed 8 x 10 prints, and it'll all show up to your humble abode with free shipping!

Limited to two backers.

8 x 10 Print Options

24 x 36 Canvas Options

 

Don't see what you're looking for? Prints are also available on my website - special requests are welcome. Also, don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions at all. 

Email: studio@petenathanson.com

Thank you for your support!

story:
APEX Express has an incredible opportunity to send one of our contributors directly to the frontlines of economic, political, and social struggles (and victories) in the Philippines.  In July, the International Conference on Human Rights in the Philippines will bring together people from across the country who are working to challenge the culture of impunity.  APEX contributor, R.J. Lozada, looks forward to capturing sound and video from this important gathering and from other parts of the country where people are fighting against big mining corporations, big landowners, and the government for land and life. 

What is APEX Express?

APEX Express is a long-running, weekly magazine-style radio show featuring the voices and stories of Asians and Pacific Islanders from all corners of our communities. The show is produced by a collective of media makers, djs, and activists and airs each week on KPFA 94.1FM.

What is this campaign for?

Over the years, APEX has shared voices from around the world including anti-nuclear work in Japan, movement against land-grabbing in India, and voices in protest from Korea.

The Philippines is one of a number of developing countries at the frontlines of land-grabbing, massive industrialization, increased U.S. military presence, and economic shifts, and APEX has brought you the voice of Angie Ipong, who at age 60 was arrested and detained for six years as a political prisoner without due process. We've shared voices from the Center for People Empowerment in Governance (CenPEG), who drew similarities between a critique of the U.S. electoral process with the electoral process in the Philippines. 

This summer, we're expanding our reporting to send one of our contributors, R.J. Lozada, to the Philippines. With the help of APEX member Marie Choi and local journalists in the Philippines, he'll gather stories from the people most affected by the issues: organizations, activists, scholars, and members of other Filipino communities in the fields, the streets, the classrooms, and offices. He'll explore how the Pacific Pivot (Trans-Pacific Partnership and military policy) exacerbates inequalities and injustices and how this has affected movement work, cultural production, and daily life. 

He'll also attend the International Conference on Human Rights in the Philippines, a gathering of human rights workers that challenge the culture of impunity. This conference is a convergence of the brightest minds within the human rights communty in the Philippines and abroad.

He will also venture to Mindanao to get perspectives of how mining compromises the ecosystem and how the indigenous communties organize against miners, and sometimes their own communities.

In addition to mining, he also plans to visit Hacienda Luisita, and observe how farmers attempt to gain autonomy and footing in true land reform -- a process that seems to be hastened by the collusion of the landowners and the Philippine government.

Finally, R.J. hopes to explore how Karaoke as a popular activity highlights the hopes, the respite, and the laughter at the end of the day.

Why is this important?

The mainstream corporate media often highlight the benefits of free trade agreements (in the name of free capital flow), and increased military presence (in the name of security). It highlights the diplomacy and agreements, but fails to articulate the local voices -- those affected and disenfrancised.

In a long tradition of providing a media outlet for oppressed voices, APEX Express recognizes the benefits of providing diverse ideas to create a strong democracy. APEX Express plans to march alongside student activists, and the urban poor during the State of the Nation address, or record the roar of distant mining cranes from a relatively untouched mountain top, or to hear footsteps and hushed voices in the halls of a government agency, it's silence, paralyzing. These scenes and access stand in direct contrast to some of the more short-sighted and problematic representations put out by the mainstream.   

What We Need

Contributions will be spent on:

- Airplane tickets to travel to, and within, the Philippines (approximately $2000).

- Local travel: jeepney, tricycle, taxi, bus.

- Equipment: While R.J. has most sound equipment, he needs a camera body to produce short videos and capture illuminating photos (approximately $700).

- Expendables: R.J. needs media cards (SD, CF) as he may be without computer and hard drives for several days.

- Conference fees (around $500).

- Fixers and translators: APEX would like to adequately support indviduals and groups that will assist in obtaining and interpreting interviews.

Note: ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE. Also, this trip will not cover R.J.'s personal amenties. This is NOT a vacation.

The Impact

APEX Express intends to create connections to international struggles with those back here in the U.S. The inequalities, injustice, hopes, and dreams that Filipina/os experience in the Philippines parallels (or is even a cause) that of struggles who are disenfranchised in the United States.

All of the reporting (radio, video, photographs) will be collected, edited, and uploaded on the APEX Express tumblr. The audio will be broadcast later this summer on APEX Express.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Visit our website for the trip: apexexpress.tumblr.com for more updates, information, and stories. Maraming Salamat, Po!

story:
What's going on in Nepal?

You probably heard about the earthquake that happened on Saturday, April 25. It was a big one – 7.8 magnitude, to be specific. More than 5,200 people have been reported dead so far, and thousands more are injured and homeless. Most media reports so far have centred on Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal, and Mount Everest, where the earthquake triggered a deadly avalanche. During ongoing recovery efforts, food and shelter is desperately needed in these areas, but also in dozens of smaller villages in Nepal's mountainous regions. It will take months and years to rebuild the lives and communities of those affected.

Why this book?

Nepal holds a special place in my heart. 

I can't quite pinpoint where my love for the country came from, but know that it started with a childhood obsession with Mount Everest, and grew into much more, following a three-month trip in 2013-14.

Like many others around the world, my heart sank when I heard about Saturday's earthquake. I was glued to my computer, refreshing for news every hour on the hour.

As concern over missing friends subsided, I was overwhelmed by the photos and stories coming out of Kathmandu and beyond. Many of the places I visited just a short time ago were now reduced to rubble. I felt a sense of unease and helplessness.

While I am in no way qualified to offer on-the-ground emergency response assistance (and please do your research – not all organizations offering 'aid' are qualified to do so), I can offer my words and my photographs. The images in this photo book were taken during my time in Nepal last year, and the text excerpts found throughout come directly from the journal I kept while in the country.

All proceeds from the sale of this book will be donated to Canada's Nepal Earthquake Relief Fund. More specifically, the money will go towards UNICEF Canada's efforts helping children and families affected by the earthquake. UNICEF has been working in Nepal for 50 years, and has 200 dedicated, in-country staff. The Canadian Government has pledged to match, dollar-for-dollar, all eligible donations that are given to UNICEF Canada and other eligible charities before May 25. 

For $25, you will get a print copy of the 35-page "Glimpses into Nepal" photo book, and a personalized thank you note from me. Any donation helps, whether it's just a few dollars, or more than the cost of the book. If you can't purchase a book, please share this fundraiser, and support what will be a long journey for those in Nepal. 

Book preview:

In case you don't want to preview the book on Blurb, here are some screenshots of what you can expect to see in "Glimpses into Nepal"

COVER:

INSIDE PAGES (screenshots):

The costs:

This photo book was created using the website Blurb.ca. You can preview the first 15 pages of the book by clicking this link. It's a softcover, semi-matte book which will take up approximately 7x7 inches of your coffee table space. I've seen Blurb's products before, and even the softcover books are beautiful and high-quality.

Here's the deal: if this fundraiser reaches its target goal, $950 will be donated to UNICEF Canada. The remaining $50 will go towards the printing costs of the book (about $11 a book if bought in bulk), and my shipping/personal delivery costs. For more of a breakdown on blurb.ca prices, you can look into their self-published book prices.

I could have sold the book through Blurb's online store, but by taking "pre-orders" for the book, I can order them all at once in bulk, which lowers the printing cost, allowing more money to go to UNICEF Canada.
story_txt: What's going on in Nepal?You probably heard about the earthquake that happened on Saturday, April 25. It was a big one – 7.8 magnitude, to be specific. More than 5,200 people have been reported dead so far, and thousands more are injured and homeless. Most media reports so far have centred on Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal, and Mount Everest, where the earthquake triggered a deadly avalanche. During ongoing recovery efforts, food and shelter is desperately needed in these areas, but also in dozens of smaller villages in Nepal's mountainous regions. It will take months and years to rebuild the lives and communities of those affected.Why this book?Nepal holds a special place in my heart. I can't quite pinpoint where my love for the country came from, but know that it started with a childhood obsession with Mount Everest, and grew into much more, following a three-month trip in 2013-14.Like many others around the world, my heart sank when I heard about Saturday's earthquake. I was glued to my computer, refreshing for news every hour on the hour.As concern over missing friends subsided, I was overwhelmed by the photos and stories coming out of Kathmandu and beyond. Many of the places I visited just a short time ago were now reduced to rubble. I felt a sense of unease and helplessness.While I am in no way qualified to offer on-the-ground emergency response assistance (and please do your research – not all organizations offering 'aid' are qualified to do so), I can offer my words and my photographs. The images in this photo book were taken during my time in Nepal last year, and the text excerpts found throughout come directly from the journal I kept while in the country.All proceeds from the sale of this book will be donated to Canada's Nepal Earthquake Relief Fund. More specifically, the money will go towards UNICEF Canada's efforts helping children and families affected by the earthquake. UNICEF has been working in Nepal for 50 years, and has 200 dedicated, in-country staff. The Canadian Government has pledged to match, dollar-for-dollar, all eligible donations that are given to UNICEF Canada and other eligible charities before May 25. For $25, you will get a print copy of the 35-page "Glimpses into Nepal" photo book, and a personalized thank you note from me. Any donation helps, whether it's just a few dollars, or more than the cost of the book. If you can't purchase a book, please share this fundraiser, and support what will be a long journey for those in Nepal. Book preview:In case you don't want to preview the book on Blurb, here are some screenshots of what you can expect to see in "Glimpses into Nepal"COVER:INSIDE PAGES (screenshots):The costs:This photo book was created using the website Blurb.ca. You can preview the first 15 pages of the book by clicking this link. It's a softcover, semi-matte book which will take up approximately 7x7 inches of your coffee table space. I've seen Blurb's products before, and even the softcover books are beautiful and high-quality.Here's the deal: if this fundraiser reaches its target goal, $950 will be donated to UNICEF Canada. The remaining $50 will go towards the printing costs of the book (about $11 a book if bought in bulk), and my shipping/personal delivery costs. For more of a breakdown on blurb.ca prices, you can look into their self-published book prices.I could have sold the book through Blurb's online store, but by taking "pre-orders" for the book, I can order them all at once in bulk, which lowers the printing cost, allowing more money to go to UNICEF Canada.

story:
Check out the website launched exclusively for "Portraits of the 99%":

http://www.Portraitsofthe99.com

All photos will be posted there from now on.

Photos published:
San Francisco Chronicle (11/19, Datebook section)

The Story

As an editorial photographer I have a great interest in human stories. When the "Occupy Wallstreet" protests spread to San Francisco I was riveted by the variety of people, and the diversity of those working together on the same goal. 

I saw an opportunity here to photograph a lot of passionate people of all ages, races and walks of life, as well as a way to spread awareness and show the intensity that is human nature.  So I set aside a day and set up a small photo studio near the OccupySF protestors and took over 60 portraits.

In less than 24 hours after posting, the images had over 4,000 views. I was getting emails from people saying the work was wonderful and inspiring. Facebook and social media spread them like wildfire. News sources picked them up.  This was when I realized that this project needed to be bigger.

My goal is to travel to the major cities in California Participating in the Occupy Wallstreet protests and setup similar mini-photo-studios and create portraits of as many of the protestors as I can. These cities include but are not limited too:

-LA
-San Diego
-San Jose
-Santa Rosa
-Oakland
-Sacramento

And the list is growing. If things go well, I may expand to other parts of the country, the ultimate goal of course, being New York.


The Impact

The ability to show the individual as a powerful person, a hero is vital to any campaign be it social, political or ethical. Raising awareness of the brave individuals involved will inspire others to take up this protest, hit the streets with their fellow man and stand up for what is right.

We need to show the world that everyone out there is rising up against tyranny - The people who wear suites, construction uniforms, scrubs, jeans, turtle-necks, tye-dye or simply shorts and a t-shirt - they are all standing strong, together.


What We Need & What You Get

The money will go primarily to flights, travel and hostels as well as food to keep myself and an assistant going. Remaining money will be donated to the Occupy Wallstreet movement. This project started on October 8th in San Francisco and I currently have contacts in Santa Rosa and San Jose. It's going, and it's not stopping. Your money will help me make it across the state, the country and if all goes will with the Occupy California fund raising, the world.
If you help out, you will certainly be rewarded with prints, posters and even a signed, limited edition book.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! If you have contacts with someone working at one of the protests (In any city in CA) drop my name and send them this link! Give em' my phone number, it's easy to find!
I'll gladly stay on someone's couch to cut costs. The more money leftover to go to the cause the better!

In general, send this page to everyone you know. Email, Facebook, Twitter, etc. Getting the word out is the most important part of this campaign!

story:
Who We Are:

     We are a group of twenty students from a Montessori middle school. Through hard work and perseverance, we are running a fundraiser to raise money by selling various products made from the results of a week of photography immersion. In our immersion week, we captured beautiful pictures of nature and interesting urban images throughout Tucson. The photographs taken were used in the creation of many products such as coasters, mouse pads, notebooks, calendars, and greeting cards. We are selling these products to raise funds for more enriching activities in the future. 

What We're Fundraising for:

The money we raise is going to give us opportunities to go on field trips and ultimately have many educational experiences moving forward. 

One of the most important field trips that the Middle School goes on is near the end of the year. We go on a three day trip to The University of Arizona’s Sky School on Mt. Lemmon. There, our focus is mostly centered around astronomy. Last year, due to the quarantine in March 2020, we did not go to Sky School. We are hoping that the COVID-19 situation will be more under control by the end of the year. 

Another valuable experience in the Middle School is Drama Week, in which students practice playwriting, public speaking and more. This year, due to COVID-19, we are going to do Drama Week over Zoom, but that will not affect the benefits that Drama Week provides. 

Our Products:

To create our unique photographs, we took high-quality pictures of nature and the things around us. Then, the images are added to our products, which include coasters, mouse pads, notebooks, calendars, greeting cards, and more. 

If you continue to scroll down, you will see the different pictures we took, which we add to our products. You are also able to choose which picture you want for the products available. 

Our Goal: 

This year, because of the unusual situation that COVID-19 has presented, we have  limited opportunities to make and sell things, but rest assured, the products we present are high quality and worth the charge. We hope that you enjoy the work we have done, and will help us reach our goal of 2,000 dollars. We would really appreciate it if you helped contribute to our cause. Thank you!

 

Here are our beautiful photos!  When you make a purchase, please try to include your photo choice with your name.  Otherwise, we'll email you to get your photo choice.

story:
An Agility Dog Life

Tucker started his online journey many years ago under the blog name "An Agility Dog Life". He was an athlete in his younger years, and I posted the trials of his career as an agility superstar for as long as he could run it. Unfortunately, at a very young age, his ACL tore. And tore again. And he retired. However, I attribute our years in agility, his ability to make me, a very shy and reserved person, stand up in front of a crowd and smile and have fun, to our incredible bond.

 

The Photography Life

Tucker retired and began following my career path as a photographer and writer. He has been the subject of all my creative ideas. He tests out props, he helps me learn my camera, and he does so with a smile on his face. There is nothing Tucker enjoys more than being in the spotlight. Or perhaps he just enjoys seeing me happy. 

Tucker is well known for his always happy face. No matter the props I put on him or the places I have him pose, he smiles. He loves life and will put a smile on the people's faces who support this venture of getting his calendar and prints out there in the world. I not only want people to be happy, but I want Tucker to be a permanent fixture in people's lives. No matter how many years pass people can look at his photos and smile. His happiness, I believe, will be contagious so long as he is remembered, which I know will be forever for me.

We have battled many trials together, and I want this one to be a fun venture for the two of us. This is the gathering of all we have done together in the years we've been a photography team. Whether you order a calendar or prints, or perhaps both, you'll be supporting our team and helping us continue our journey together. 

What You Get

Depending on what you pledge, you can get all kinds of fun Tucker goodies! 

Examples of products will be uploaded as I get them in stock!

Traditional Calendar - You will receive a 12-month calendar with 12 beautiful and happy photographs of Tucker. Each will reflect the month to a certain degree by coinciding with the time of year, or holidays present during that month. Calendars are 8x11" and are spiral bound. The Traditional Calendar features a mix of costumed and "naked" Tucker photos.

Costumed Calendar - Looking for a calendar featuring only costumed photos? Look no further! New this year is a calendar full of only costumed pics designed for those who enjoy the quirky and fun personality of Tucker's modeling career! Calendars are 8x11" and are spiral bound.

"Pawtographed" Prints - Tucker will be signing prints for those lucky enough to nab one of those slots! Prints will be completely random and unrelated to holidays so they can be used year-round if you wish to display them. Paw print will be a pet-safe paint print of one of Tucker's paws. It will appear somewhere on the photograph that does not interfere visually with the photograph (generally the bottom right).

Tucker Painting - NEW this year! Tucker will be making paintings out of a pre-cut stencil of himself!

Regular Prints - If you buy one of the print packages, you will receive a variety of high-quality prints according to what the description says. Prints will be RANDOM and may include holiday images (though not all will be, by any means!)

The Impact

Where Does the Money Go?

Printing is a huge cost. In order to make printing prices go down, we need to buy calendars in bulk. This requires people pledging to purchase calendars in advance of them being printed. Additionally, the time that will go into making the calendar, making the prints, and all the time that has went forward to making the photographs, of course, is of value. 

Consider this: an average photo shoot lasts 30 minutes. An average photo shoot varies in price depending on props, which can average around $1.00-$20.00 each. This adds up, and of course, I'm glad to do it since these are memories I am making with my amazing dog. However, it is an expensive hobby and I'd love to expand on it! Additionally, editing photos generally takes 5+ hours. Now you can see the love that goes into each photograph I take of Tucker. 

After printing and shipping costs, proceeds will go to furthering our photography venture through the purchase of props, toys, and anything else that makes Tucker smile! By supporting this product you will be supporting my photography career, but more importantly, Tucker's happiness! I'd love nothing more than to show him opening up goodies for months to come after this project is complete, and you'll all get to see it via social media! Isn't that exciting?

**For those who have expressed interest in shelter donations being made via this venture in the past: Please be aware I have spent countless hours donating my photography skills to shelters, and in the future (one we do not want to think about), his props will be donated to shelter photography shoots to help promote shelter animals. Due to the risk of disease spread, I am not currently photographing for dog shelters as Tucker's health is not at its best. This will resume in the future, and I do volunteer time with a local horse rescue. This venture is solely about Tucker and I assure you I do many noble causes on the side :) 

Risks & Challenges

We may not reach our goal, which has been set to allow me to properly print & ship products. Without this goal, calendars would cost people around $30.00 each, which I want to avoid charging. By funding this campaign I hope to allow more people to obtain calendars, and perhaps some other Tucker goodies! Some other challenges to keep in mind:

Printing and shipping takes time. I hope to have calendars out to people by January. If we have reached our goal early I will get calendars ready to be printed immediately to help prevent delays. 

I appreciate any understandings for delays or snags in the road. I will do my best to supply you, my backers, with high-quality products to my best ability in a reasonable time.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot purchase anything, please, please share this campaign! People will not be disappointed with looking at Tucker every month for a year :)

Share this campaign on social media - everything helps!

Ask family members for these products for gifts! Even if they are late for Christmas, remind people, continuing the Christmas spirit with late gifts is always fun!

Continue to follow and support Tucker and my photography business in every way you can by sharing and following our social media outlets.

@CrevanNight on Instagram

@SpringerTuck on Instagram

Facebook.com/CrevanNight

Facebook.com/SpringerTuck

Can't buy a calendar? That's ok! We've provided some cheap alternatives to help support the campaign and still receive some fun goodies. Every bit helps.

We appreciate any help you can give us to continue our dreams of providing smile-worthy photographs.

story:
Short Summary

 My name is Bob Coleman and I have been a photojournalist for more than 25 years. In 2011 and 2012, I joined the mission team at St. Vincent de Paul Church in Rogers, AR to document their work in Haiti. The parish of St. Vincente de Paul supports the 14 schools and one high school of St. Francois by paying for the building and maintaining of schools, providing books and school supplies for the students and paying the salaries of the teachers and administrators.

Each year the mission team goes to Bombardopolis and checks on the work that has been done over that year and the progress of new projects. My job with the team was to photograph the students, the schools, and new projects in progress, and to help the parishioners in Rogers get a better picture of what life in Bombardopolis is like. The video (above) is the result of those visits and s used during the annual appeal to parishioners for future support of the mission.

There have been many changes since my last visit in 2012 and in a few short weeks, I will return to Bombardopolis to update my photos and the video. Most importantly, I will document the first high school graduation and the students who have worked so very hard to graduate. In addition to photographing the graduation day festivities, I will be making a series or portraits and conduct video interviews with these students to be used at the high school and back home in Rogers.

My immediate goal to finish funding the trip. I recently had a company sponsor back out of his pledged funds for business reasons he said were out of his control.That money would have been used to buy some essential photo and video accessories necessary to complete the job and a couple things in a wish list for use on the trip.

The most pressing things are memory cards for the video interviews, a portable hard drive to back up all my work, a video microphone, a variable grade neutral density filter for shooting video outdoors, and a lightweight travel tripod for the video interviews. 

Finally, while not essential, I would love to bring a Fujifilm Instax instant camera and film to be used at the school visits. The students love it when they are able to get a picture of themselves and it helps me establish a positive relationship with them while I go about doing my work.

The Impact

There is a Haitian proverb, “Sa je pa wé, ké pa santi -   What the eye doesn’t see, the heart doesn’t feel.” It is my hope that when people view the work I will be producing their eyes will see and their hearts will feel some of what mine did when I made these images.This is the first ever graduating class from St. Francois d'Assise. Three students will receive scholarships to the university in Port au Prince.The impact on those students remains to be seen, but their story can help other students in the Bombardopolis schools be inspired to stay in school and graduate. The story can also inspire students here in Arkansas. 

Risks & Challenges

Even though I have tried to coordinate time with the students with both the pastor of St. Francois and the administrators of the high school, nothing in Haiti is certain - even plans you thought were all worked out. I will get to photograph the graduates, I just do not know if I will have as much time as I hope to have with each one. One thing I have learned in the 25 plus years I worked in the newspaper world is to adapt and overcome obstacles to reaching your goal. That will be the theme of this trip.

In addition to photographing the graduation day festivities, I will be making a series or portraits and conduct video interviews with these students to be used at the high school and back home in Rogers.
My immediate goal to finish funding the trip. I recently had a company sponsor back out of his pledged funds for business reasons he said were out of his control.That money would have been used to buy some essential photo and video accessories necessary to complete the job and a couple things in a wish list for use on the trip.
The most pressing things are memory cards for the video interviews, a portable hard drive to back up all my work, a video microphone, a variable grade neutral density filter for shooting video outdoors, and a lightweight travel tripod for the video interviews. 
Finally, while not essential, I would love to bring a Fujifilm Instax instant camera and film to be used at the school visits. The students love it when they are able to get a picture of themselves and it helps me establish a positive relationship with them while I go about doing my work.
The ImpactThere is a Haitian proverb, “Sa je pa wé, ké pa santi -   What the eye doesn’t see, the heart doesn’t feel.” It is my hope that when people view the work I will be producing their eyes will see and their hearts will feel some of what mine did when I made these images.This is the first ever graduating class from St. Francois d'Assise. Three students will receive scholarships to the university in Port au Prince.The impact on those students remains to be seen, but their story can help other students in the Bombardopolis schools be inspired to stay in school and graduate. The story can also inspire students here in Arkansas. 
Risks & Challenges
Even though I have tried to coordinate time with the students with both the pastor of St. Francois and the administrators of the high school, nothing in Haiti is certain - even plans you thought were all worked out. I will get to photograph the graduates, I just do not know if I will have as much time as I hope to have with each one. One thing I have learned in the 25 plus years I worked in the newspaper world is to adapt and overcome obstacles to reaching your goal. That will be the theme of this trip.

story:
It's a Snap! has invited 22 collectors from around the country to share a few of their favorite snapshots in a group show.  Some of those photos will be for sale as well.   As far as I know, there has not been a show on the East Coast which has brought together so many well known collectors of snapshots to be a part of such an important event.

The show will take place at MAP (Mill Arts Project) at Eastworks in Easthampton, Massachusetts.  MAP is giving me the opportunity to develop my curating and marketing experience via this upcoming exhibit of photographs.  The show will run for the month of February, with the opening night party on Saturday, February 14th, coinciding with Art Walk Easthampton.

Confirmed collectors contributing snapshots to the show include:

Steve Bannos
Peter Cohen
Randall de Rijk
Maria DiElsi
John Foster
Mark Glovsky
Clare Goldsmith
Richie Hart
WM Hunt
Robert E. Jackson
Nigel Maister
Sabine Ocker
Nicholas Osborn
Billy Parrott
John Phelan
Ransom Riggs
Estelle Rosen
Joel Rotenberg
Ron Slattery
Albert Tanquero
Erin Waters
John Van Noate

OUR GOAL IS TO RAISE $3500 FOR THIS PROJECT

Your donations will help cover basic costs including:

$1250 Printing of color catalogs and calendars.
$250   Promotional costs including postcards, posters and signage.
$1250 Preparing the photos to be hung, including matting and framing.
$500   Postage costs for returning the art to the collectors
$250   Special event costs during the show.

I'm very excited about curating this event and I hope that you can help me make it the best show possible!   Thank you!!

story:
Savoring the world only takes place when you all get along.

The world makes no sense without friendship.

-  Rwandan Proverb

Thank you for taking the time to visit our page; we hope our story will help inspire you to help the children of Rwanda while getting a fantastic book (and more) in the process!

In September 2014, my wife and I completed a 20 year dream and got to visit the mountain gorillas of Rwanda. We experienced all that Rwanda had to offer in an unforgettable five day adventure. From the bustling capital city of Kigali to the beautiful mountains of the Volcanoes National Park, it was a breathtaking experience from start to finish.

During our trip, we visited a local school that is supported by the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund and got to spend time with some truly inspiring children who touched our hearts and left us wanting to help them further. This school is the children's opportunity to be educated, learn English as a second language and make a better life for themselves.

The gratitude shown towards us was one of the most genuine and moving experiences of our lives. We'll never forget the looks of joy and the cheering we heard from the dozens of children that surrounded our car when we gave them a soccer ball that we had hand carried from the US... Their appreciation for something we think of as so simple left us wanting to do more.

With that, we came up with the idea of creating a photo book of our travels to share our experiences and give back to the local community. We're looking for your help to support a wonderful cause: directly helping Bisate School in Rwanda, which is part of a group of organizations supported by the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund. http://gorillafund.org/about_us.

While our main campaign finished in December, we have now signed up to Indiegogo's InDemand option which means the campaign can continue raising money here indefinitely; so thanks for your time and we hope you can help!

This campaign is to raise enough money to directly help the school by first building a basketball court for all of the children to use and from there we can look at other ways to assist. Since completing this campaign, we are raising money in a range of different ways; you can visit our Facebook page here: https://www.facebook.com/5daysinrwanda

Alternatively, please visit our art and photography site via Fine Art America: http://paul-weaver.artistwebsites.com/ all proceeds go to charity so we hope you'll be able to find a way to help, whatever you can do helps the cause!

Thank you in advance for your contribution and support; even helping to spread the word is what helps to make crowd-funding work.  

We appreciate any and all help you can give us!

Paul and Nicola

Our Story

My wife and I met in the summer of 1994 and became fast friends with an awful lot in common.  One of those things was a love of mountain gorillas, which came from watching movies going all the way back to the original King Kong but encapsulated in the movie Gorillas in the Mist.

It was always our dream to visit the gorillas in person, but at the same time we always felt it would be one of those “bucket list” items that we’d never really achieve. I’m happy to say that twenty years later we achieved our goal and got to experience these magnificent creatures in person, but as it turns out, our trip ended up being much more than that.

                                                                                          Picture: Kigali, Rwanda

In our short time there we got to experience Rwanda; a country that’s been through its own share of heartache and pain, but has managed to survive, grow and even thrive. Our visit included a heartbreaking trip to the genocide memorial, but also an uplifting visit to a local school being supported by the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund.

Getting to be there in person was always a privilege, but being able to meet the local community, see their way of life and most importantly to experience truly friendly, hopeful and good people touched us so much that we wanted to find a way to give something back.

                                                                                  Picture: Bisate Public School, Musanze 

This book is our way of saying thank you to the people of Rwanda and to help the children of the Rangers, Guards, Guides and Porters who help keep the gorillas safe.

Here's some details on the book:

·  72 pages – A mixture of full page and smaller collections of pictures including landscapes, wildlife, the people of Rwanda and of course, a whole section devoted to the gorillas.

·  10 x 8 inches – Full-color, hardcover photography book, printed and published by www.blurb.com

·  Price – £50 RRP (+ £12 international Postage and Packaging)

·  Ship Date – The book is now available and will be delivered quickly with a campaign donation that includes it as a perk.

Our costs… and what you get in return

The journey is done, the photographs have been taken and the book has been completed; we have received our first printed version for final review. Now we need your help to reach the finish line.

· We have included a number of perk levels and we are thankful if you can even share our campaign; anything and everything you can do to help is appreciated!

·  At the highest donation levels I am extremely pleased to offer you a unique piece of artwork as a digital wallpaper, postcard, fine art print or canvas giclée of one of the Silverbacks we met on our journey digitally painted by the incredibly talented former Disney artist, Mark Stefanowicz http://www.markstef.com/gallery.html

·  Mark's techniques are derived from the 17th century Baroque Era and with his use of layering colors, the light bounces through them to the canvas and back to give you the most vivid image imaginable. A truly unforgettable, magnificent gift!

· As you can hopefully see, we've made a very high quality book (and depending on your contribution, some beautiful artwork too). The book is being professionally printed by www.blurb.com and we’re delighted with the quality; we’re sure you will be too.

· Shipping costs are included in the prices, but please note that these cover shipping within the United States only. There is a higher level perk and for that we’ll be able to ship anywhere in the world.

These are photos of our first printed version, which should give you a good idea of the final quality of what you are getting:

Please help spread the word and make this possible

Please take the time to share this site with friends and family and help spread the word. Your individual help can make a huge difference to the success of this project and is greatly appreciated. Thank you!

·  Tell your friends, family & others why this should be supported

·  Please share our story on Facebook, Google+, Twitter, Pinterest, etc

·  By all means, spread the word worldwide to any media source that might be interested!

·  Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

    The Impact

    Spending time with the children of Rwanda was a life changing experience for us; please be part of this campaign to help make a positive difference in their lives!

story:
From Mountains to Molehills - Faces of Longboarding
Sunday morning, at a longboard-contest somewhere in Germany.
Saturday was already great, I had a good time shooting all the nice, crazy, beautiful, inspiring and highly talented people who came together to have a good time skating on those long wooden planks. I grab my camerabag, my longboard, a coffee and start again. Another day in baking sunshine, seeing faces, meeting longboarders from all over europe, making friends. And document everything on film. 

I spent some of the best days of the past two years like this, travelling from mountains to molehills, documenting the longboard-scene surrounding me. All the dancers, freeriders, downhill-racers, sliders, cruisers, slalom-geeks, all the die-hard-ladies and all the nice gentlemen I met on the hills, the parks and streets ... amazing.
»Faces of Longboarding« is a series of portraits and moods that provides a deep insight into the scene, a close look at people who really love that lifestyle, who travel from one end of europe to the other with no money, no sponsor, but tons of love and dedication.

After two years I want to return some of the love I received, with this campaign I want to raise money to print a photobook with a best of of all the portraits I took. Preorder your book here, along with a limited screenprint or a set of postcards!

Who am I?
My name is André Kniepkamp, I'm a selftaught photographer who works and lives in Cologne, Germany. After long years of skating and surfing, I started longboarding a few years ago. Fascinated by the diversity of the scene I began with my »Faces of Longboarding«, an analog photo-project I was working on for the last two years.
You can find the photos on my blog or follow the project on facebook.

What I need and what you get
I‘m going to print at least 500 hardcover-photobooks on FSC-certified 300gr paper at a print shop in Germany that focusses on sustainablitity regarding the use of paper, printing ink, electricity and shipping. The book will contain more than 150 analog photos on 120 pages! Furthermore I‘ll offer a set of postcards and a limited edition of numbered and signed screenprints on 250gr. recycling-paper in A3. (29,7x42cm) See a preview here! Each boook will be signed by me, too.

You can preorder your book here to make this all happen! 5700€ are needed to print 500 copies of the photobook and 100 screenprints, any cent above that goal is used to print more books, organize an exhibition and to cover productions-costs like film-development, scanning, etc. If the goal is not reached, your money ist not wasted of course! The book will be printed, because I strongly believe in that project and I hope you do, too. 

If you can‘t or don‘t want to spend any money, that‘s ok.
You can still help with sharing the link on facebook or any other social media platform using the menue on top of the page.


1% For The Planet
I'm member of 1% For The Planet, that means, I obligate to donate 1% of my sales for the planet, pledging to support non-profit organizations focused on sustainability. So by buying the book you support the environment, too. Great, isn't it?
1% For The Planet is an alliance of businesses that understand the necessity of protecting the natural environment. They understand that profit and loss are directly linked to its health, and are concerned with the social and environmental impacts of industry. Learn more about 1% For The Planet
