story:
ENGLISH ///

http://www.facebook.com/DawsonAECCommercialPhotography

THE PROGRAM We are the Dawson College Commercial Photography Graduates of Spring 2013. The goal of this program is to give graduating students the technical, visual & business skills to perform commercial tasks typically done by self-employed or staff photographers in a manner that meets industry & professional standards. We have been instructed in various aspects of professional photography including advertising & editorial illustration, portraiture, catalogue photography, architectural photography, fashion photography, industrial photography & digital imaging. In courses designed to cover both theory & practice, we learned to use small & large format cameras, tungsten & electronic flash for studio or location lighting, & computer imaging software for output & media applications. Throughout the program, a mature & disciplined approach to commercial photography was emphasized & at the same time, we were encouraged to develop a personal creative vision of the world.
 
THE VERNISSAGE We have finally reached the culmination of all of our work – it is time to graduate, & exhibit our work to friends, fans, potential clients & buyers. We will be holding a Vernissage at Dawson College, & we are in need of contributions to further our potential for success as we head into the workforce. That is where you come in -- your money will be helping to fund our Vernissage in order to make it the most impressive visual presentation possible.
 
THE GOAL We have 1500$ granted to us by the college, but that only goes so far with nearly 20 graduates. We are hoping to raise a total of 6000$. This money will go to the matting & potential framing of portfolios, producing our promo book, refreshments for the exhibition, printing of posters & so on. Regardless of whether we reach our entire goal or not, the money will be going straight to the Vernissage – we will produce our exhibition in the most economical & visually inspiring manner with the funding we have. The more funding we have, the more effective our exhibit will be.
 
THE IMPORTANCE Some of us will soon be off to find employment in the field as assistants or employees, whereas others will be diving head first into opening their own studios & businesses. This is not the only portfolio we will ever produce, but for many of us this Vernissage is a golden opportunity to get a head start in the industry here in Montreal. The reason this Vernissage is so important is due to the fact that industry professionals will be viewing our work -- these guests may provide possible business ventures for us in the future, & we want to impress. We understand that not everyone can contribute a monetary value to our campaign -- however, you can still help by spreading the word or donating goods & services to our exhibition. We really appreciate your help!

 

----------------------------------------------------------------

FRANCAIS /// 

http://www.facebook.com/DawsonAECCommercialPhotography

LE PROGRAMME   Nous sommes les diplômés du Collège Dawson en Photographie Commerciale pour le printemps 2013. L'objectif de ce programme est de donner aux étudiants diplômés, les compétences techniques, visuelles et d'affaires qui respectent les normes professionnelles de l'industrie. Nous avons été formés dans les divers aspects de la photographie professionnelle : publicité, éditorial, illustration, portrait, photographie de catalogue, photographie d'architecture, photographie de mode, photographie industrielle et imagerie numérique. Les cours étant destinés à couvrir à la fois la théorie et la pratique, nous avons appris à utiliser des caméras avec des capteurs de petits et grands format, des lumières tungstène et des flashes électroniques pour l'éclairage de studio ainsi que les principaux logiciels informatiques d'imagerie et des applications multimédia. Tout au long du programme, une approche éprouvée et disciplinée à la photographie commerciale nous a été transmise et en même temps, nous avons été encouragés à développer une vision personnelle de la création et du monde.

LE VERNISSAGE    Nous avons finalement atteint le point culminant de tout notre programme, il est temps d'obtenir nos diplômes et de présenter notre travail aux amis, fans, clients potentiels et acheteurs. Nous organisons un vernissage au Collège Dawson, et nous avons besoin de votre contribution pour assurer la réussite de cette soirée importante.  
 
L'OBJECTIF   1500 $ nous sont accordés par le collège, mais cela ne couvre pas toutes les dépenses pour le vernissage de 17 diplômés. Nous espérons recueillir un total de 6000 $. Cet argent ira à l'encadrement des photos, la production de notre livre promotionnel, des rafraîchissements, et bouchées lors du vernissage, la location de panneaux pour l'accrochage des photos, l'impression d'affiches et ainsi de suite. Tout l'argent récolté ira directement au vernissage. Nous allons produire notre exposition de la manière la plus économique et visuellement stimulante avec le financement que nous aurons. Le plus de financement nous aurons, la plus efficace sera notre exposition !
 
L'IMPORTANCE   Certains d'entre nous seront bientôt à la recherche d'un emploi dans le domaine comme assistants ou employés, alors que d'autres seront plongés tête première dans l'ouverture de leurs propres studios et/ou entreprises. Pour plusieurs d'entre nous, ce vernissage est une occasion en or pour prendre un bon départ dans l'industrie ici, à Montréal. En effet, des professionnels de l'industrie seront présents lors de cette soirée et nous souhaitons les impressionner. Nous comprenons que tout le monde ne peut apporter une aide monétaire à notre projet, cependant, vous pouvez aussi aider en diffusant le mot ou en donnant des biens et/ou services. Nous apprécions grandement votre aide. Merci pour votre contribution !
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
 

TRADITIONAL CORPORATE SPONSORSHIP

ADDITONAL FUNDRAISING EFFORTS

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

story_txt:
ENGLISH ///
http://www.facebook.com/DawsonAECCommercialPhotography

THE PROGRAM We are the Dawson College Commercial Photography Graduates of Spring 2013. The goal of this program is to give graduating students the technical, visual & business skills to perform commercial tasks typically done by self-employed or staff photographers in a manner that meets industry & professional standards. We have been instructed in various aspects of professional photography including advertising & editorial illustration, portraiture, catalogue photography, architectural photography, fashion photography, industrial photography & digital imaging. In courses designed to cover both theory & practice, we learned to use small & large format cameras, tungsten & electronic flash for studio or location lighting, & computer imaging software for output & media applications. Throughout the program, a mature & disciplined approach to commercial photography was emphasized & at the same time, we were encouraged to develop a personal creative vision of the world.
 

THE VERNISSAGE We have finally reached the culmination of all of our work – it is time to graduate, & exhibit our work to friends, fans, potential clients & buyers. We will be holding a Vernissage at Dawson College, & we are in need of contributions to further our potential for success as we head into the workforce. That is where you come in -- your money will be helping to fund our Vernissage in order to make it the most impressive visual presentation possible.
 

THE GOAL We have 1500$ granted to us by the college, but that only goes so far with nearly 20 graduates. We are hoping to raise a total of 6000$. This money will go to the matting & potential framing of portfolios, producing our promo book, refreshments for the exhibition, printing of posters & so on. Regardless of whether we reach our entire goal or not, the money will be going straight to the Vernissage – we will produce our exhibition in the most economical & visually inspiring manner with the funding we have. The more funding we have, the more effective our exhibit will be.
 

THE IMPORTANCE Some of us will soon be off to find employment in the field as assistants or employees, whereas others will be diving head first into opening their own studios & businesses. This is not the only portfolio we will ever produce, but for many of us this Vernissage is a golden opportunity to get a head start in the industry here in Montreal. The reason this Vernissage is so important is due to the fact that industry professionals will be viewing our work -- these guests may provide possible business ventures for us in the future, & we want to impress. We understand that not everyone can contribute a monetary value to our campaign -- however, you can still help by spreading the word or donating goods & services to our exhibition. We really appreciate your help!
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
FRANCAIS /// 
http://www.facebook.com/DawsonAECCommercialPhotography

LE PROGRAMME   Nous sommes les diplômés du Collège Dawson en Photographie Commerciale pour le printemps 2013. L'objectif de ce programme est de donner aux étudiants diplômés, les compétences techniques, visuelles et d'affaires qui respectent les normes professionnelles de l'industrie. Nous avons été formés dans les divers aspects de la photographie professionnelle : publicité, éditorial, illustration, portrait, photographie de catalogue, photographie d'architecture, photographie de mode, photographie industrielle et imagerie numérique. Les cours étant destinés à couvrir à la fois la théorie et la pratique, nous avons appris à utiliser des caméras avec des capteurs de petits et grands format, des lumières tungstène et des flashes électroniques pour l'éclairage de studio ainsi que les principaux logiciels informatiques d'imagerie et des applications multimédia. Tout au long du programme, une approche éprouvée et disciplinée à la photographie commerciale nous a été transmise et en même temps, nous avons été encouragés à développer une vision personnelle de la création et du monde.

LE VERNISSAGE    Nous avons finalement atteint le point culminant de tout notre programme, il est temps d'obtenir nos diplômes et de présenter notre travail aux amis, fans, clients potentiels et acheteurs. Nous organisons un vernissage au Collège Dawson, et nous avons besoin de votre contribution pour assurer la réussite de cette soirée importante.  

 

L'OBJECTIF   1500 $ nous sont accordés par le collège, mais cela ne couvre pas toutes les dépenses pour le vernissage de 17 diplômés. Nous espérons recueillir un total de 6000 $. Cet argent ira à l'encadrement des photos, la production de notre livre promotionnel, des rafraîchissements, et bouchées lors du vernissage, la location de panneaux pour l'accrochage des photos, l'impression d'affiches et ainsi de suite. Tout l'argent récolté ira directement au vernissage. Nous allons produire notre exposition de la manière la plus économique et visuellement stimulante avec le financement que nous aurons. Le plus de financement nous aurons, la plus efficace sera notre exposition !

 

L'IMPORTANCE   Certains d'entre nous seront bientôt à la recherche d'un emploi dans le domaine comme assistants ou employés, alors que d'autres seront plongés tête première dans l'ouverture de leurs propres studios et/ou entreprises. Pour plusieurs d'entre nous, ce vernissage est une occasion en or pour prendre un bon départ dans l'industrie ici, à Montréal. En effet, des professionnels de l'industrie seront présents lors de cette soirée et nous souhaitons les impressionner. Nous comprenons que tout le monde ne peut apporter une aide monétaire à notre projet, cependant, vous pouvez aussi aider en diffusant le mot ou en donnant des biens et/ou services. Nous apprécions grandement votre aide. Merci pour votre contribution !

IF you would like information about Traditional Corporate sponsorship packages for your business.  Please contact the Program Director Ms Laurel Breidon (lbreidon@dawsoncollege.qc.ca).  Please use the subject "VERNISSAGE SPONSORSHIP"

story:
UPDATE: We have reached our £8,000 goal with 21 hours left to go. Thank you, Thank you, Thank you so much for all of the support so far.

 

There are still a number of rewards left, and we will continue taking donations as a result. Any money raised on top of the £8,000 goal is going to be used in order to ensure that the whole exhibition is exactly as we want it. There is a lot of work to be done in the next two weeks and we're excited to open our doors to you on the 14th of July. One love!

 

Statement of purpose: What is Finding Soul about?

Rohan Ayinde, Tayo Rapoport and Yewande “YoYo” Odunubi are three strands of the multi-vibrational movement of soul-vibe-bringers, Touching Bass.

“Finding Soul” is their artistic collaboration, offering you a unique experience that is grounded in an appreciation and deep respect for the energy or “soul” of the people they move with.

Starting with a series of portraits made by Rohan over the past two years, this exhibition is built around the premise that community, and the substance that holds any community together, is powerful, necessary, beautiful and important to share.

Combining Rohan’s photography and poetry with Tayo’s filmmaking and YoYo’s spatial curation, this is about building an environment in which you are best placed to experience and be moved by an energy that we find constant inspiration from.

We are passionate about making this exhibition happen for a number of reasons:

First, as artists dedicated to making work that moves people and has the ability to spark discussion and provoke thought, we want to put this on for the simple desire to share.

Second, as members of a community that we are inspired by, we want “Finding Soul” to create an environment which explores the essence of this inspiration and allows you to meditate on how to nurture your own spaces that reflect and/or complement the journey the exhibition takes you on.

Lastly, we think that it has never been more important to examine and think about the importance of being part of communities that provide support, stimulation and purpose in a moment of increasing social fracturing and individualism. For us, starting a conversation and reflecting on the substance that brings and holds us together is the beginning of knowing how to build the kinds of spaces needed to challenge the structures that keep us divided.

Where + When + What else?

Finding Soul is being exhibited at Blank100, 100 De Beauvoir Road, Unit 5, London, N1 4EN

From the 14th – 16th of July

Opening Night: On Friday the 14th of July we’ll be having an opening evening of discussion that will serve as an introduction to the space and will set the energy for the following two days. Expect mellow vibes, good conversation, a bit of bubbly and great people.

 

Closing Night: On Sunday 16th of July, join us for an evening of “pure vibrations” in collaboration with Touching Bass. This event will be a way to bring all the energy from the exhibition into a set of live performances. Expect poetry, music and a laid-back, meditative vibe. Details and tickets will be released soon.

 

 

The breakdown: How much is it going to cost?

In order to make this exhibition as strong as possible and to allow us to pay close attention to the finest of details necessary to curate an experience that is cohesive, engaging and comprehensive we are aiming to raise £8,000.

Below is a percentage breakdown of the costs: 

• Printing and Framing the photography – 50%

• Venue hire, hanging, lighting, buying materials and transporting everything to and from the space – 25%  

• Producing, editing and colour grading the final piece of audio-visual work – 8%

• Indiegogo and card fees equal 8% of total money contributed, which means that if  when we’re successful we’ll have to shell out about £640 to Indiegogo and pals

• And lastly we have to account for miscellaneous costs alongside fulfilling any rewards for all your warm, deeply appreciated and welcomed help

which leads us perfectly into the fun part:

The perks: What do you get in return for your support?

Your support, no matter how big or small, is what will make this exhibition a success – so, from the jump, we want to say thank you for anything you are able to contribute.

All of the rewards are listed to the right →

Some of the highlights:

Soul Brother: We’re really excited to offer a limited edition chapbook of writing and photography by all three artists. This is a special piece of work for us, and will provide another piece of inspiration for anyone that comes to the exhibition (and a taste of what it was all about for those of you who are unable to make it).

Soul Selector: We’re also excited to be able to offer a choice of one of four signed prints from the exhibition. Each print is 50 x 70 cm and will be printed on Archival quality, Fujifilm C-Type Matt Photographic paper. Please see the options below:

Image 1

Image 2

Image 3

Image 4

•••

We are running a fixed campaign, so if we don’t make all the money we set out to raise, we will not be able to put this exhibition on. With this in mind, every single one of you is as important to this exhibition as we are and we can’t wait to curate a space for all of you to experience, meditate on, and come away feeling inspired by. So, even if you can’t donate to the Indiegogo please share this with your friends and family, chat about it with your colleagues and come along once we’ve put it all together – these things are just as important as donating money (And doing both would be amazing ;))

The photos: Will they be on sale?

Of course – All of the original framed and signed photographs from the exhibition will be on sale. There is a range of sizes available, from 50 x 40cm to 70 x 100cm. Each framed print will have a limited run of five.  If you can’t make it down on the weekend, but are interested in buying something, please get in touch with us and we will send you a digital brochure with all the photos for you to choose from.

The Artists: Who, exactly, are they?

If you’re still reading (and haven’t just donated eight grand to pay for everything) it’s probably because:

1) You’re like Rohan and you just love reading Indiegogo Project Pitches

or

2) You want to know a little more about the three of us: who we are, what work we’ve done and what we’re hoping to do in the future.

Bios

Yewande “YoYo” Odunubi

Yewande “YoYo” Odunubi is a London based curator and youth programme facilitator passionate about curating environments that nurture and create space for creative collaboration.

Working with a range of cultural organisations including the Southbank Centre, Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA) and A New Direction, and grassroots London collectives BBZ and Touching Bass, YoYo has spent the last five years supporting programmes that give emerging creatives agency and opportunities to drive their own creative learning and cultural participation.

IG: @mama.yoyoreturns

 

Tayo Rapoport

Tayo has been carrying a video camera since the age of 17. It is this intrinsic pull towards the documentation of the everyday that has stimulated his creative endeavours. Tayo’s focus has always been cultural exploration, how can we bring each other closer through art? How can we find more empathy for one another? How can we expand our understanding of ourselves? Tayo is always looking to shine a light on the real and the surreal within life’s daily offerings.

"Imagine your fondest memory and how that makes you feel.”

Over the past couple of years Tayo had been creating intimate documentary films - profiling some of South London’s most prolific jazz musicians in the project ‘Sampled: What is World Music?’ and creating cinematic portraits of underground culture + music scenes, from London, to New York, to Kingston Jamaica. Recent commissions include 'Night + Day Brixton’, featured on DAZED, a documentary for the UK band The xx, and ‘Manhood’ a documentary for UK fashion brand TOPMAN. His latest endeavour is CHILD studio, a production company that looks to create ‘Inspiring visual art - whilst retaining values of integrity, sustainability & equality’

Website: www.tayorap.com

IG: @tayo.rap

 

Rohan Ayinde

Rohan Ayinde is an interdisciplinary artist whose work is dedicated to creating spaces of empowerment and reflection for marginalised people. He has described his work as being “committed to creating an audience that is Black without the limitations of race.” Using both photography and poetry, Rohan views art as his most powerful means of stimulating dialogue and action that has the means to change the world.

Rohan is a member of the Roundhouse Poetry Collective, was a finalist in the 2016 Roundhouse Poetry Slam and has performed for WorldWide FM, Levi’s and the V&A as well as performing at The Church of Sound. A member of the grassroots London collective Touching Bass and an organiser for Take Back the City, London plays a significant role in shaping his work. However, this year he will be leaving the city to do a Masters in Visual Critical Studies at The School for the Art Institute of Chicago to study black visual culture and its importance on/in/for movements of resistance.

Website: www.rohanayinde.com

IG: @rohanayinde

Facebook: Rohan Ayinde

•••

This is our last chance to say thank you, so thank you. We hope you’ve felt inspired to become a part of making Finding Soul come to life.

And lastly, lastly, we want to holla at y’all again to say that whether you have contributed £8,000 to straight up fund this whole thing or dropped a £1 in to show your love in hard times, we love and appreciate you. Literally every donation helps and the more people that:

know about this project,

                   share it and show love for it,

the closer we will move to achieving our goal – to connect, to create and to share good vibes!

So yeah, use the Indiegogo sharing tools and spread some soul on all your social media platforms

Respect,

Tayo, Rohan and YoYo.

story:
Short Summary:

Hello, 

My name is Anton Orlov and I am a photographic artist based out of San Diego, California.  I love traditional photography and have been printing my own black and white images for the past 23 years.

2012 saw the birth of The Photo Palace Bus - traveling darkroom and gallery.  This was my dream for the past 15 years and I am very happy to see it come to life. 

The aim of The Photo Palace Bus is public education about the beauty and importance of traditional printmaking methods with the goal of inspiring the use of analog photography. While traveling Photo Palace offers the following programs:

• History of the Photographic Medium Exhibits

• Magic Lantern Slide Shows

• Worshops in Darkroom Techniques

• Alternative Printing Methods Workshops and Demonstrations

• Portrait With Instant Imaging Technology

• Darkroom Consultations

and more....

You can get a good idea of my personal dedication by taking a look at the BLOG, which I kept during construction and the inaugural 9.300mi journey from California to Maine and back.

During the second journey I would also like to compile a comprehensive survey of the state of analog photography today.  This will be done by conducting interviews with people associated with fine art photography focusing on traditional means of printmaking.  The interviews will appear on the blog and eventually published in a limited edition book.

The first of the interviews are already being conducted in San Diego area. 

Your support means a lot to me.  Any amount that you are comfortable with contributing will indeed make a big difference.

What We Need & What You Get:

The $10.000 goal will go toward the following:

• Construction of a foldout portrait studio mentioned in the kickstarter campaign - to make it RIGHT it's going to cost in the range of $3500-4000 (while converting the bus my personal funding simply ran out just short of being able to do that)

• Fuel and other traveling expenses

• Limited edition book publication

• Printing supplies such as paper and chemistry

• The rest will go to indiegogo and Paypal fees and expenses of printing and shipping the perks

Perks:

After the end of the campaign you will receive the wonderful perks that you chose.  The list is on the right so feel free to take a look and see what you feel tickles your fancy.

Books will be printed at the end of the project (I project that to happen at the end of the summer) .  Please read through the list carefully and make a selection (or two or three -  nothing says you can’t contribute more than once, right?)

Are you in Continental United States?  One of the perks involves Gilli swinging by your town and giving a private lecture on historic processes illustrated by my collection of prints. 

The $700 Perk - Unique Gelating Silver Mural Prints.

Here is a link to the gallery of prints where you can chose one for yourself:

http://orlovphoto.com/galleries/guetemala/

The first two prints (Self Portrait and Incense Seller have been sold and are NOT available)

The rest of the imges are printed in edition of 1 each (except for Lake Atitlan which was printed in edition of 2).  These 30x30in fiber base silver ptints are truly beautiful and were printed on Foma Chamois Cream Tone paper giving them a wonderful old-world feel.  They were all captured on Rolleiflex TLR cameras and have stunning detail and clarity.  These are some of the best prints I have ever made (definitely the best mural prints by me).  It is impossible to reproduce them as the paper manufaturer has switched paper base and it no longer has the luster and texture that it used to have.

As soon as a print is sold I will post a note about it here so you know what you have left to chose from.


Here is an example of the amazing detail of these prints.  Take a look at the image called 'Memory' and then take a look at this little close-up which is still not really as sharp as the real print.

 

 

The Impact:

My blog has been getting an ample amount of hits from all over the planet.  Readers come from all over the planet - North and South America, Europe, Asia and occasionally Africa and Australia as well.  Along with enjoying the adventurous and raw style of my writing I hope it inspired them to pick up that old Brownie, dust off their fathers Leica or invest into a 4x5.

By exposing the passion and the impetus of the artists working manually I hope to inspire a new generation of printers and innovators.  By providing folks with a list of both photo educational facilities and manufacturers of analog products I aim to give more business to them in the long run. 

In the age when digital technology is expanding and changing faster than any one person can keep up with I hope to inspire people to discover the rewards that are brought by devoting their time and labor to making a print via analog means.  The magic of seeing a print emerge in a developer still touches many hearts.

As I pointed out my dedication to this cause is 110% - did the unsuccessful end to the kickstarter campaign stop me from investing every dime of my savings into this unique project?  No way!  I labored for months and spared no expense in making the presentation area and darkroom into an inviting and pleasant place to be in.  After that I took Gilli-the-Gillig on the road. Thousands of people were exposed to and educated about the history of photography though impromptu lectures and demonstrations.  The warm reception I received along the road inspired me to keep going and now I need your support.

Other Ways You Can Help:

There are a few ways you can help other than financial support (though that is what this project needs most)

• Let me know who you think I should interview.  Do you know someone who makes exquisite photo gravures?  Maybe you are friends with the manager of the film division of Kodak or Lomography?  Perhaps you know a high school or university photo teacher who has been inspiring young minds for decades now and loves what they do? 

• HUGE help would be you posting this campaign on your Facebook page, in photo groups there or on other sites or just e-mailing the link to it to a good friend or family member who you know is in the fortunate position to be able to offer financial support to a dedicated artist.
story_txt:
Short Summary:
Hello, 
My name is Anton Orlov and I am a photographic artist based out of San Diego, California.  I love traditional photography and have been printing my own black and white images for the past 23 years.
2012 saw the birth of The Photo Palace Bus - traveling darkroom and gallery.  This was my dream for the past 15 years and I am very happy to see it come to life. 
The aim of The Photo Palace Bus is public education about the beauty and importance of traditional printmaking methods with the goal of inspiring the use of analog photography. While traveling Photo Palace offers the following programs:
• History of the Photographic Medium Exhibits
• Magic Lantern Slide Shows
• Worshops in Darkroom Techniques 
• Alternative Printing Methods Workshops and Demonstrations
• Portrait With Instant Imaging Technology
• Darkroom Consultations
and more....
You can get a good idea of my personal dedication by taking a look at the BLOG, which I kept during construction and the inaugural 9.300mi journey from California to Maine and back.
During the second journey I would also like to compile a comprehensive survey of the state of analog photography today.  This will be done by conducting interviews with people associated with fine art photography focusing on traditional means of printmaking.  The interviews will appear on the blog and eventually published in a limited edition book.
The first of the interviews are already being conducted in San Diego area.  
Your support means a lot to me.  Any amount that you are comfortable with contributing will indeed make a big difference.
What We Need & What You Get:
The $10.000 goal will go toward the following:
• Construction of a foldout portrait studio mentioned in the kickstarter campaign - to make it RIGHT it's going to cost in the range of $3500-4000 (while converting the bus my personal funding simply ran out just short of being able to do that)
• Fuel and other traveling expenses
• Limited edition book publication
• Printing supplies such as paper and chemistry
• The rest will go to indiegogo and Paypal fees and expenses of printing and shipping the perks
Perks:
After the end of the campaign you will receive the wonderful perks that you chose.  The list is on the right so feel free to take a look and see what you feel tickles your fancy.
Books will be printed at the end of the project (I project that to happen at the end of the summer) .  Please read through the list carefully and make a selection (or two or three -  nothing says you can’t contribute more than once, right?)
Are you in Continental United States?  One of the perks involves Gilli swinging by your town and giving a private lecture on historic processes illustrated by my collection of prints.  
The $700 Perk - Unique Gelating Silver Mural Prints.
Here is a link to the gallery of prints where you can chose one for yourself:
http://orlovphoto.com/galleries/guetemala/
The first two prints (Self Portrait and Incense Seller have been sold and are NOT available)
The rest of the imges are printed in edition of 1 each (except for Lake Atitlan which was printed in edition of 2).  These 30x30in fiber base silver ptints are truly beautiful and were printed on Foma Chamois Cream Tone paper giving them a wonderful old-world feel.  They were all captured on Rolleiflex TLR cameras and have stunning detail and clarity.  These are some of the best prints I have ever made (definitely the best mural prints by me).  It is impossible to reproduce them as the paper manufaturer has switched paper base and it no longer has the luster and texture that it used to have.
As soon as a print is sold I will post a note about it here so you know what you have left to chose from.
Here is an example of the amazing detail of these prints.  Take a look at the image called 'Memory' and then take a look at this little close-up which is still not really as sharp as the real print.

story:
Short Summary

Thousands landed at Normandy on D-Day, and every day their number dwindles.  I want to go document this years ceremonies while some still remain, to capture the images and stories that I can, so that they are saved for generations to come, so that they are not lost in the sands of time.

What I Need & Why

What I am seeking is at least $6500.00 for three weeks to meet survivors and others; document as muc as I can; and, process that into things that can be shared:

• $2000 -- transportation, and while this seems high, it costs more than this to get there if I am in Afghanistan as I hope to be

• $1000 -- lodging, and the closer I get the more expensive it gets

• $750 -- Car rental, with full insurance

• $1050 -- per diem: food, drink, fuel, and other expenses

• $800 -- monthly insurance costs for my travel/embed insurance

• $900 -- fees associated with fundraising

Anything raised above this will go to:  computer upgrades for improved processing capabilities; travel/combat insurance costs; improved photographic capabilities; and, other expenses of doing this trip and/or embeds with U.S. and Allied troops.  If total funding is not raised, donations will go towards:  fees, travel/embed insurance, lodging, airfare, and rental car.  I will make it stretch as far as I possibly can.

What You Get

You should get something too, so:

• $1-$49:  a thank-you e-mail

• $50 donation:  electronic copy (watermarked) of the Normandy stained glass window seen above

• $100 donation:  limited signed/numbered edition 8x10 print of the stained glass photo, limited to 25 donors

• $500 donation:  limited signed/numbered edition 11x14 print of the stained glass photo, limited to 15 donors

• $1000 donation: personalized signed edition 11x14 print of the stained glass photo; and, special thanks in an e-book showcasing this year's events

• $2500 donation: personalized signed edition 11x14 print of the stained glass photo;  special thanks in an e-book showcasing this year's events; and a thank you post on my blog and on Blackfive online military magazine

• $5000 donation:  special personalized & signed print of the stained glass photo; special thank you page in an e-book showcasing this year's events; a thank you post on my blog and on Blackfive online military magazine; and, credit as a sponsor of all posts about this year's Normandy ceremonies on my blog and Blackfive online military magazine.

Prints to be delivered as soon as practical after funds are received. Electronic items will go out as soon as possible. 

The Impact

The veterans of D-Day are fast leaving us.  Of those that are left, very few will be able to make the trip this year, and as for next year, it is possible that we may see no veterans there.  My goal, my dream, is to go document this year's events, the participants -- and, where possible, their stories.  I want to share what I do via posts on my blog and at Blackfive online military magazine; via video; and, through e-books and maybe even a print book that shares the images of today for future generations.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise!

•  Get the word out to friends, families, companies, and anyone else who might can help with this.

•  Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Most of all, thank you!  Everything helps

story:
One sleepless night I had a crazy idea, an idea so crazy that it just might work...

I thought to myself, what if I could take a series of photos that showed the beauty of the human body without specifying a gender and allow the viewer of the imagery to decide for themselves if they found the image attractive or not.

 

Once the first set was complete I decided that the content and quality would simply not be done justice by Facebook or other digital display.

I decided a gallery exhibition was how I wanted to show this work, at least initially.

The cost of this is going to be several thousand dollars to achieve, and I am asking for help with the framing and presentation of the imagery, which is approx NZ$200/image, I would like to display at least 10 images, which means I need to raise at least NZ$2000 (US$1618).  The  more I raise the more images I will create.

If the funds exceed the amount by enough I will be able to expand the exhibition, and hopefully create a free App or Website to present the imagery in the best light.

I'd also love to go beyond digital and experiment with Large Format photography for this subject to be able to create HUGE prints, life size  or larger.

The Impact

I would really like to get this imagery out into the public face, and expand on the concept, to show that some males can be feminine, and females masculine, and both as beautiful.

The impact I hope will to be to generate acceptance of masculinity and/or femininty not being restricted to or limited by gender.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, on facebook, twitter, text, email, tell your Mum and your Dad, tell their Mum and Dad too, and your garden gnome while your at it.

 

 

A video will follow to help with the campaign, but I'm currently ridden with flu, and look as bad as I sound.

story:
About the project

In 1977 photographs by American photographer Chuck Fishman, appeared in a book called Polish Jews: The Final Chapter. All of them were taken in 1975, when Fishman visited Poland for the first time as a student. They were a record of his meetings with Polish Jews living in the realities of People’s Poland — the last survivors of the Shoah and the few descendants of a community that had once numbered three million, but had been nearly wiped out in the Holocaust and further diminished by subsequent waves of post-war emigration.

The photographs by Fishman, who visited Poland several more times in the 1970s and 1980s, set out to capture the final chapter in the history of Polish Jewry. Fishman sought to perpetuate the memory of a community disappearing before his very eyes. He worked mainly in large cities, formerly important Jewish centres, where Jewish life somehow still ‘smouldered’. He took photographs in Kraków, Wrocław and Warsaw, as well as in Lublin, Łódź and Przemyśl, where only a handful still cultivated their Jewishness.

The systemic change of 1989 had an enormous impact on Jewish life in Poland. For many, it meant the possibility of rediscovering their roots, reconstructing their Jewish identity, exploring their ancient traditions or being able to discuss openly the complex Polish-Jewish relations. The process of the revival of Jewish communities began. On leaving Poland in 1983, Fishman could not have imagined the photographs he would take 30 years on in democratic Poland. His pictures from the 2010s often feature laughing young Jews of the third and the fourth generation after the Holocaust.

43 years have passed between the taking of the earliest and latest photographs presented in the exhibition, making Fishman’s project one of the most comprehensive photographic records of European Jewry in the second half of the twentieth and the beginning of the twenty-first centuries. In the first part, the exhibition features photographs presenting the realities of the 1970s and 1980s. When viewed from today’s perspective, these images, now etched in the consciousness of people around the world, reflect stereotypical ideas about the continuing realities of Jewish life in Poland.

However, the earlier vision is almost deliberately supplanted by another one emanating from the photographs displayed in second part of the exhibition: depicting a diverse and rejuvenated community pursuing their normal lives, albeit “in the shadow of Auschwitz”.

All of the photographs are in black-and-white. The artist took a conscious decision to document contemporary Jewish life in Poland with the same artistic resources he used in the 1970s and 1980s. This treatment not only makes the entire collection visually coherent, but also demonstrates that the atmosphere or significance of photographs is not driven by the chosen black-and-white tones — the new photographs emanate optimism, energy and hope.

In addition to the Fishman’s photographs the photobook will also include essays by the renowned journalists, artists and historians Konstanty Gebert, Stanisław Krajewski, Ruth Ellen Gruber and Jason Francisco. As a result, the publication will have an impact beyond the exhibition’s run time by preserving the story of the unique transformation of Jewish Poland for future generations.

About Chuck Fishman

In his 40-year career, freelance photographer Chuck Fishman has focused on social and political issues with a strong humanistic concern. His work has been extensively published, exhibited and collected worldwide, and has earned him prestigious World Press Photo Foundation medals four times. His photographs have appeared on the covers of Time, Life, Fortune, Newsweek, The London Sunday Times, The Economist and numerous others, and have been selected for publication in the American Photography and Communication Arts juried annuals. Fishman’s work is included in the collections of the Smithsonian National Portrait Gallery; the United Nations; POLIN The Museum of the History of Polish Jews; The Center for Creative Photography, University of Arizona; The Studio Museum in Harlem; and Hogan Jazz Archive, Tulane University, among many others, as well as in private and corporate collections.

Fishman takes his photos standing somewhere on the side, but his attentive gaze remains in them. There is nothing particularly important about them – the fleetingness of the moment, the banality of predictable, cyclic events: prayer services, meetings, funerals. On the mound on Miła Street in Warsaw, children roll on the grass. You almost miss that not far away there are people laying flowers and lighting candles at the memorial stone.

/Konstanty Gebert/

 

In the 1970s, he photographed Polish Jews as a miserable, melancholy and tragically inadequate remnant of the pre-war community. Everything was pointing to decline. The young people appeared to be an exception which did not threaten the rule. That rule was a vision of “the last chapter”. The end of Jewish life was supposed to occur when those who remembered the pre-war times had passed away, and it would certainly occur when those who could recall the first two decades after the war, when attempts at reanimation of the community were made under the watchful eye of Jewish communists, were gone.

/Stanisław Krajewski/

 

Chuck Fishman set out more than 40 years ago to chronicle with his photographs the “final chapter” of 1,000-year Jewish experience in Poland. But he failed!

Returning to Poland decades later, he has continued to photograph Polish Jews and Jewish Poland. But far from a final chapter, he is now chronicling an expanding, multi-faceted, ever-unfolding story – and long may he do so!

/Ruth Ellen Gruber/

From one perspective, Fishman’s view is elegiac, a vision of what remains after physical and cultural genocide, Jewish life as a balance between the fragile and the resilient.  From another perspective, Fishman’s view is defiant, a vision of life pressing forward through loss, the Jewish world doing more than just holding onto itself, but thriving oyf tsu lokhes the losses and brutality of the last three quarters of a century in Poland. 

/Jason Francisco/

 

This series – or rather two series – of Chuck Fishman’s photographs is extremely personal. It shows the almost non-existent world of the Jews in Poland in the 1970s, right up until today after the Re-Generation as in the exhibition’s title.

Chuck’s photographs show the photographer as an outstandingly meticulous observer of Poland’s Jewish society. He appears to be standing in the shadows, but it turns out that he is precisely in the middle of what is happening - or paradoxically not happening – in front of him. And that is exactly what this type of photography is all about.

/Chris Niedenthal/

 

There is no better time than now, when truths of history and memory are being challenged, to shine a light on a body of work that photographer Chuck Fishman has dedicated more that 40 years, a collection of images, rare and unparalleled, not only as authentic documents of Polish-Jewish life in a bygone era, but also for bearing witness to the birth of new generations.

With honesty, sensitivity and passion, Chuck Fishman tells a moving story of peril and promise, a universal tale of survival and rebirth of Polish-Jewish life spanning four generations.

As a photographer, Chuck Fishman has donned the mantle of caretaker; his body of work serves not only to keep Jewish cultural memory and history alive in the last quarter of the twentieth century, but also to illuminate, for the global community, the rebirth of Jewish identity in Poland as it is unfolding at the dawn of its second millennium.

A legacy for future generations, Fishman’s photographic narrative traces the footprints of history—the story of the near-demise and stunning rebirth of Polish-Jewish identity—and represents a watershed moment, poised to change world understanding of a defined people… A rare perspective into an exceptional moment in time.

With caring, intensity and passion spanning four decades, Chuck Fishman has documented the near-demise and rebirth of Poland’s one vibrant Jewish community.  This people, whose roots reach back a thousand years, who survived both annihilation by Nazism and fifty years of crushing Communism, are now re-emerging in a democratic Poland.  Their ‘return to identity’ is an incredible story whose time has come.

/Michael Schudrich, Chief Rabbi of Poland/

 

Film credits:
Chuck Fishman in the Keret House, Warsaw 2013
Artist–in–Residence at the Keret House
Organiser: Polish Modern Art Foundation
Co–financed by: City of Warsaw

It shows the almost non-existent world of the Jews in Poland in the 1970s, right up until today after the Re-Generation as in the exhibition’s title.Chuck’s photographs show the photographer as an outstandingly meticulous observer of Poland’s Jewish society. He appears to be standing in the shadows, but it turns out that he is precisely in the middle of what is happening - or paradoxically not happening – in front of him. And that is exactly what this type of photography is all about./Chris Niedenthal/ There is no better time than now, when truths of history and memory are being challenged, to shine a light on a body of work that photographer Chuck Fishman has dedicated more that 40 years, a collection of images, rare and unparalleled, not only as authentic documents of Polish-Jewish life in a bygone era, but also for bearing witness to the birth of new generations.With honesty, sensitivity and passion, Chuck Fishman tells a moving story of peril and promise, a universal tale of survival and rebirth of Polish-Jewish life spanning four generations.As a photographer, Chuck Fishman has donned the mantle of caretaker; his body of work serves not only to keep Jewish cultural memory and history alive in the last quarter of the twentieth century, but also to illuminate, for the global community, the rebirth of Jewish identity in Poland as it is unfolding at the dawn of its second millennium.A legacy for future generations, Fishman’s photographic narrative traces the footprints of history—the story of the near-demise and stunning rebirth of Polish-Jewish identity—and represents a watershed moment, poised to change world understanding of a defined people… A rare perspective into an exceptional moment in time.With caring, intensity and passion spanning four decades, Chuck Fishman has documented the near-demise and rebirth of Poland’s one vibrant Jewish community.  This people, whose roots reach back a thousand years, who survived both annihilation by Nazism and fifty years of crushing Communism, are now re-emerging in a democratic Poland.  Their ‘return to identity’ is an incredible story whose time has come./Michael Schudrich, Chief Rabbi of Poland/ Film credits:Chuck Fishman in the Keret House, Warsaw 2013Artist–in–Residence at the Keret HouseOrganiser: Polish Modern Art FoundationCo–financed by: City of Warsaw

story:
The story - Why are we singing so loud? 

There were several events that lead to the birth of When The Blackbird Sings in 2016. The abundance of tiny streams heading on the same route to finally rejoicing and creating that huge roaring flood, tearing through the landscape of both subconscious and social structures.

How shall I put it?

2016 was pretty tough. . It was a combination of the loss of a grandmother and world leaders who seemed high on testosterone, meanwhile I was overdosing on another hormone to create life. It never grew, but another seed came to develop. A seed that was for Her and the female aspects of Earth. In the darkness of last years super new moon I knew that it wasn't my story I sought to tell, it was HERstory. I knew that to make me stronger I had to I truly see Her. 

I  photographed women during a whole year; every full and new moon and only at twilight. 

Each twilight is heralded by the song of the blackbird. In this role, the blackbird is cast as a messenger, here to remind us of our mortality and vitality.  Her song also gave me refuge all through last year. The bird called me into awareness of my ever-changing nature and my inner cycles. When The Blackbird Sings’ specifically consider the lunar-led bonds and binds of time in fertility; the changing seasons as being a dialogue with our own inner cycles; how these periods are represented in nature. 

In spring 2016 I was holding my grandmother's hand in the hospital. Her thin hand reminded me of a leaf in the end of November. It was a diaphanous piece, baring veins and structures in the most delicate way, it was like the only life she had left inside her was shining through her thin luminescence skin. I still miss her, immensely. 

Birth and Death - The Ultimate Creation

I know it sounds like tall tale, but with these life changing events The Blackbird started to sing. The bird sang so loud I knew that I had to carry on photographing. The work brought a great group of women together and what a group.  Women,  you know who you are;  my mother, friends, daughters, witches and grandmothers.  You are proud and strong women, baring yourself during the L’Heure Bleu showing the surrounding  world how we are all full of life and blood. 

 

 

Why am I here at Indiegogo?

I have now 24 (for all the new and full  moons during 1 year) pieces that will be exhibited in 2018 at Arusha Gallery here in Edinburgh/Scotland. The show is going up on the first of March and  taken down 5 days after the Spring Equinox. 

I am now looking into funding phase two; frames, print and event.  I know that is just one line, BUT its essential.  The photographs will need to enter our world, to actually exist (something we can touch).  Can you help?

How can we exchange energy? What can I do for you? I have some top suggestion here, but I am open for a collaboration and discussion around support and finances. 

If you just share this campaign you will be a part of it and I am grateful. In the end of the day we are here together. Believe it or not. 


The Blackbird sang too loud for both Facebook and Instagram 

Blocked from both Instagram and Facebook: This happened so many times it was actually doing my head in. Meanwhile the President (don't mention his name) was talking about "grabbing them by the" a female nipple gave me a 30 days "break" from Facebook.  They have kindly informed me that if I post anything that doesn't follow the community guidelines again I might loose my account. 

 

​I mentioned this already;  this is not my story anymore, its Her story.

I  would like her voice to echoing loud across the land. Her stories about life. If you listen closely you will soon hear that her story is also your story.  Lets make this exhibition happen please. 

Jannica Honey xx

Come and sing with us 

https://www.instagram.com/whentheblackbirdsings_/

story:
Hello!

My name is Paige Ormiston and I am currently working towards a double major in both Computer Science and Design at Western Washington University. I am passionately in love with photography and have devoted myself to taking a photo every day for 1 year, known as my Project 365.

A few weeks ago, I was visiting a friend in Bellingham and brought along my brand new 13" Macbook Pro in order to post my photos of the day for the weekend. During the 8-10 person get-together, someone knowingly spilled water on my keyboard and refuses to confess to their accident. Even people who claim to have witnessed it happen are still "clueless" as to who did it.

After shipping my laptop off to Texas for Apple repair, I am now facing up to $755 in damages, and simply cannot afford to pay for someone else's mistake. Right now, I am left with a broken laptop, and a complete feeling of betreyal and hopelessness.

Without a fixed laptop, I cannot continue on with the Design program in the fall, and it is difficult to pursue my beloved Project 365 as well as other photoshoots and side projects.

_______________________

 

Anyone who knows me well, knows that I hate asking favors. However, I am turning to those who have supported my photography and other hobbies from the beginning, and asking for help to continue doing what I love most.

 

Any donation, no matter how big or small, will mean the world to me. Thank you so much!

story:
Greetings!

As a "local voyager" of communities near and far, I am about to embark on the next leg of my photographic journey: the 1000 Shillings program has offered me a unique and powerful oporutnity to work as a photography fellow in Namatala, Uganda this summer.

1000 Shillings is a non-profit dedicated to women's empowerment in developing nations. The organization provides six local Ugandan women artists with a global marketplace for their products and microgrants to start their own sustainable businesses. These efforts aim to alleviate poverty for these women and their families, effecting tangible change in their lives. Through this fellowship, I will work closely with the women of Namatala and other 1000 Shillings fellows as we share their stories and strive to connect our global communities. It is thrilling to be a part of this meaningful and cooperative enterprise.

The funds raised through this campaign will cover my travel and living expenses in Uganda, a portion of which will also support the women artists with whom we work. To learn more about 1000 Shillings and its mission, please visit www.1000shillings.com.

Thank you for your support!
 
Cheers,
Meredith

story:
This Christmas I am offering everyone a chance to take a sneak peek at my new show AND SCORE prints that will only be available through this campaign.

I am a filmmaker and photographer so my photos very often tell stories. This show is a collection of images that explore outlaws in many forms, from Bonnie & Clyde type pairings to spies to hitmen or maybe even hitchicks, some mobsters, some Serbian Crime Lords. Who knows. We'll see.

This show will obviously have weapons of many kinds and while I shy away from complete nudes because they cannot hang in most public venues, I do lean towards the sexy and I do show skin (both dudes & dames).

This photography exhibit is titled "Outlaws"  though I have affectionately termed it "Guns & Bunnies". I am using a lot of different 35mm cameras for this shoot and a variety of film. I have pulled out some of my LOMO cameras to achieve certain effects. This is old skool photography. Real film. Real limited edition signed prints.

I am doing something I have never done with this crowd sourcing. I am offering certain prints ONLY through this Indiegogo. That means that getting on board here will be the ONLY way to ever receive a signed print of select photos from this show. AGAIN ... I WILL ONLY OFFER CERTAIN PRINTS through this campaign. Come one. Come all. And get your limited edition signed prints of Outlaws. This show is a whole lot of awesome. If crowd sourcing is really about the participation then I believe this is the BEST way to show thanks. If you are a part of "Outlaws" then you will be rewarded by prints only available to YOU. Because you are the audience and you ROCK.

Bang Bang. Get your outlaw on, guys & dolls.

You can learn more about me here:

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Lis-Anna-Photography/102943693121857

And here http://bluerumor.wix.com/lis-anna-author

And here http://www.flickr.com/photos/99943370@N04/

And here https://twitter.com/Bluerumor     

      

And here... oh, you get the picture.

story:
Student Photographers today have a mountain to climb; to stand out from the crowd, yet embrace tried and tested techniques; to create their own niche or appeal to the masses.

This collection of work demonstrates the drive and determination of the University of Derby’s current Commercial Photography third-year students. They have embraced their respective areas of expertise, collaborated, and engaged with the commercial environment; built upon the knowledge base of their university education, and are already sharing their abilities within the photographic industry.

LUX'13 presents the work of Commercial Photography students graduating from the University of Derby this summer.

Their work demonstrates a broad spectrum of applications, including 3D imaging, motor sport and celebrity photography. Among the award winning young artists, two of their number have been shortlisted for Student Photographer of the Year for their respective fashion and still life photography.

The city recently hosted the Format Photography Festival, within which the students have taken active roles, from assisting festival Patron Brian Griffin, to hosting live photography projects for participants from around the world.

LUX'13 Commercial Photographers will be exhibiting at the degree show in Derby at Markeaton Street Campus from 31st May to 11th June 2013, and the renowned Menier 'Chocolate Factory' Gallery in London from 25th-29th June. Come along and meet the next generation in Commercial Photography.


However, funding is still necessary before the exhibition can take place. We have calculated that £500 is still needed in order to pay for brochures, invitations, other printed advertisments. The money will also go towards our private view night for our London exhibition.

 

Links:

www.lux13.co.uk

www.twitter.com/lux13exhibition

www.facebook.com/lux13exhibition

story:
No shadows with Completely White Background


Brighter Light Source up to 6,500 Lux for the Clearest Images





                         



 


 





              

      







      




The rise of the Internet and e-commerce prompted the birth of iPhotoBox Lite.
You can shoot professional product images in just 1 minute with iPhotoBox Lite, whether shooting difficult jewelry, or glass or mirror products prone to serious reflections and inverted image problems, so that your photography requirements can be satisfied for products made with variety of different materials.


iPhotoBox Lite has 40CM and 60CM versions to suit photographing products of different types and sizes and different customer needs. We have complete product research and development, patent registration and product prototyping. The next step is crowdfunding activities. Our goal is to produce the iPhotoBox Lite prototype, and we expect to ship batches of the product within one month of the completion of crowdfunding. 


           


                      



         



         

                


                      

           


           






The rise of e-commerce prompted us to develop the iPhotoBox Lite Studio Kit to provide more effective product photography solutions for new Startups, SMEs and even large multinational companies

We always used to hear our friends constantly worrying about shooting product images. They always ran into many problems, for example, spending a lot of time preparing photographic equipment or adjusting the lighting angles. Taking a series of products photos might take several days or even two weeks. Sometimes they had to spend money to hire photographers in order to save time, but it was often costly. So we started to develop the Studio Kit, and set out to create a professional quality shooting, but affordably priced, portable professional small studio to solve the problems of Startups and various SMEs. Users do not need any photographic experience. You can experience the magic of product photography just with an ordinary digital camera or mobile phone.






FAQ


Free Shipping ?

Free shipping covers the courier shipping costs to US, Canada, Europe, South East Asia, Japan, Korea and Australia and does not cover VAT or additional country taxes. Customer clearances will be responsible by the Buyers. Please feel free to contact us if you are shipping to other areas for the additional cost. 


How the warranty works? 

We provides a 2 years fully covered warranty service subjected to manufacturer's defects. For products received within 3 days from arrival and confirmed to be a manufacturer's defect, we will replace a new iPhotoBox Lite to you at our cost including courier charges. Most of the component of the iPhotoBox Lite can be easier detached for repair. Repairing process will take place in Hong Kong and Buyer will be responsible for the courier charges. 


What to do if I have problems when using the iPhotoBox Lite? 

We understand you may have many questions on installation and operations even though the Photo Box is very easy to use. Therefore, we will provides you with a 3 months Online Technical Support and our support team will be very happy to assist you and turn yourself to be a professional photographer. 


What is 7 Days Return Money-back Guarantee? 

For all EASY DEAL Buyers, we are pleased to offer a 7 days return money-back guarantee. No questions ask and simply return the full set of packing (with original packaging and accessories) to our Hong Kong headquarter within 7 days after receiving of your goods. Payment will be returned to Buyer by PayPal and the relevant bank charges will be at Buyer's costs. After deducting the first courier costs from Hong Kong to your country, we will be reimbursing US $ 440 for the 40cm iPhotoBox Lite or US $ 661 for 60cm iPhotoBox around 7 days after receiving of your return set in Hong Kong. 


Do I need to replace the LED? How long does it last? 

We are using the top quality LED Chips from Samsung and therefore, quality and performance can be ensured. The LED light panels are very durable and normally can last up to 10,000 hours.


Who is iPhotoBox Lite for?

iPhotoBox Lite is definitely a landmark design. It is suitable for users with no photographic technique, whether you are a new Startup that needs to take product photos or an old shop with a large number of inexpensive products to photograph, iPhotoBox Lite can satisfy your requirements so that you can do all your product photography without the help of a professional photographer. you can create professional photography anywhere and anytime and save yourself a lot of money.

At the same time, iPhotoBox Lite is also suitable for professional photographers. Photographers usually spend a lot of time with professional lighting layout in a professional studio to capture professional photo effects. Now, iPhotoBox Lite can save you a lot of time, which you can spend being more creative. iPhotoBox lite's preset professional lighting layouts achieve excellent performance in showing a product's true texture and layering, making it easy to shoot on a shadow-less pure white background and deal with post-production work.

story:
Our Story

Hello My name is Kelly Karnesky and I want to make art for the rest of my life. 

I fell into concept photography sometime in 2007 and I've been running with it ever since. In 2009, a few of my good friends insisted I should charge and Kelly Karnesky Photography was formed. As I developed as a photographer, I noticed my day job getting more and more in the way of what truly made me happy. The idea of making a piece of art that can influence someone is extremely rewarding to me.


I love art and I want to make a living creating it. But I can't go anywhere living day to day hoping I make enough money for food yet alone gear. I'm asking for contribution you can afford to help make my dreams come true. 




The Impact

I believe one mind can change the world. I believe that through art, I have a chance to change the mindset of society and make a difference, and that's exactly what I intend to do. I'm not your typical "look at these beautiful flowers" type of photographer. The concepts behind my photographs have the power to inspire ideas and change perspectives. I want to make powerful images for powerful minds.



What We Need & What You Get


I need a new camera (mine only 2 years old is way out of date)

I need more and better lighting systems

a few new lens's would great increase the quality of my work

Budgets for big concept photoshoots. so far I've been doing everything on a free budget I am a DIY kinda guy but it only gets you so far I would like to be able to pay for Make up artist/models/amazing locations.

A new computer mine has a habit of restarting whenever it wants, it barley runs the editing software I use.

 


Other Ways You Can Help

The best thing you can do for me besides donating is posting on your wall asking people to help support me!

any support you give would mean a lot.
story_txt:
Our Story
Hello My name is Kelly Karnesky and I want to make art for the rest of my life. 
I fell into concept photography sometime in 2007 and I've been running with it ever since. In 2009, a few of my good friends insisted I should charge and Kelly Karnesky Photography was formed. As I developed as a photographer, I noticed my day job getting more and more in the way of what truly made me happy. The idea of making a piece of art that can influence someone is extremely rewarding to me.

I love art and I want to make a living creating it. But I can't go anywhere living day to day hoping I make enough money for food yet alone gear. I'm asking for contribution you can afford to help make my dreams come true. 




The Impact
I believe one mind can change the world. I believe that through art, I have a chance to change the mindset of society and make a difference, and that's exactly what I intend to do. I'm not your typical "look at these beautiful flowers" type of photographer. The concepts behind my photographs have the power to inspire ideas and change perspectives. I want to make powerful images for powerful minds.



What We Need & What You Get

I need a new camera (mine only 2 years old is way out of date)
I need more and better lighting systems
a few new lens's would great increase the quality of my work
Budgets for big concept photoshoots. so far I've been doing everything on a free budget I am a DIY kinda guy but it only gets you so far I would like to be able to pay for Make up artist/models/amazing locations.
A new computer mine has a habit of restarting whenever it wants, it barley runs the editing software I use.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
The best thing you can do for me besides donating is posting on your wall asking people to help support me!
any support you give would mean a lot.

story:
I am a photographer. the death of my camera has left me without. I need a new camera. And now I will get it.

 

I once had a sony DMC RX-100. It was my pride and joy. when I bought it, it became my primary camera. (I have a not so portable 5d) . It was small. I could fit it into my shirt pocket. I could take it anywhere. it produced amazing photographs. I NEED TO ADD SOMEWHERE THAT ALL FUNDS ABOVE AND BEYOND THE ORIGINAL 1200.00 WILL BE SPENT ON SUPPLIES. 

now i have a broken and mangled piece of electronics.  but my third eye is coming 

replacing it will bring me out to the streets again doing what I love.

contribute what you can. and by all means pass this message along to anyone that you know who might want to help. thank you for your support.

 

To see available images (though a case could be made for another) go to https://www.facebook.com/bobrobadu/media_set?se...

story:
Hi I'm Shelley!

My name is Shelley Koon.  I'm a photographer who finds beauty in the forgotten and damaged. My photography career spans over 30 years with the last three focusing on photographing abandoned structures.

I'm running this campaign to assist in funding the printing, matting and framing of my photos for my first solo exhibit "Wither: Exploration of the Forgotten." 

Why should you send me your hard earned dollars?

I put a lot of time and energy into my art - it truly is my passion, heart, and soul. This exhibit is a fantastic opportunity for me to get my art in front of a broader audience of both patrons and those in the art industry (gallery directors, photo directors, etc.) that could lead to more work, bigger projects, and more access into the abandoned areas I love so much.

What will I do with your hard earned dollars?

I'll  print, mat, and frame 20 - 25 prints for the show.  The cost for each print is $114 dollars so I'm looking at roughly $2,900 - $3,300 total.

I've saved enough to cover a third of that, but when I get into the higher numbers I start considering selling kidneys...  Joking!  Kind of...

I still have other costs associated with the show such as music, hors d'oeuvres, wine/beer, soda and water which I will be covering myself - I'm just looking for help with printing and framing.

I've put together some perks that I'm pretty excited about.  These are far below market value but I am excited to give out some really cool stuff to those who support me in making this show happen!

When you help me, you help us all.

I have the honor of knowing so many great photographers who focus on abandoned structures and spaces.  By helping me with my exhibit you help this genre of photography gain exposure and further legitimize its inclusion in a gallery setting.  This opens up opportunities for other photographers as it encourages collectors and appreciators of fine art photography to seek out similar work.

Other Ways You Can Help:

I totally get not being able to assist monetarily (that's the whole reason I'm running this campaign right?) but there are other things you can do to support me that do not require pledging dollars!

Please share this campaign with your social community!  Indegogo makes it easy with the sharing tools!

If you're local come to the opening of the exhibit!

story:
My name is Mickey Aloisio and I’ll be graduating from the Fashion Institute of Technology in May. I have been working on my senior thesis for two years now. I decided to create a body of work of gay bear men as a way for me to be a part of the community and meet new people. Below is a short statement describing the project: 

“Gay Wildlife” brings together images from two years of venturing into the homes of heavier gay men within New York City and the surrounding areas to explore issues of identity, body image and belonging. This work speaks about the specific tendency within gay culture to lump people together into categories based on the archetypes of their body.

This project is presenting the chance to get inside of one of these supposedly explanatory groupings known as bears, and show the diversities and the multitudes of expression and personalities within it. The resulting images of these men and the domestic spaces they inhabit, examine how each subject is so very distinct, as well as their precise regard for the camera. In a lot of ways, Gay Wildlife is a direct continuation of my interest in and exploration of what it means to be a gay male in todays society. 

This project is important to me because I came to the city two years ago and up until that point I had no gay friends, never went to a gay bar, nor have I ever really participated in any type of gay event. Then, because of this project I’ve had the chance to explore all over the city and it's surrounding boroughs in order to meet a bunch of new and incredible people. Since then I have made some very important and close friends and have created terrific bonds with them that I hope will continue to remain a lasting friendship. 

By contributing to this project you will be helping to create an edition of books of this body of work. I am hoping to be making 50 copies of the book.  I'm a student right now who's in the process of graduating and I do not have the money I would need in order to create the books on my own. Making a book is very expensive, but the more people that are interested in buying one, the less the cost of making the books become. Making a book means that this work will be in the hands of more people. I think its important to have work that celebrates subcultures within the gay community, as well as celebrating issues of body image, acceptance and belonging out in the world. By supporting young queer artist’s spread their vision, art and hard work we are supporting the success and the aiding mentality of LGBT community as a whole. We are together making something that is very meaningful to so many people.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sean and I like to document the world. I went to school for photography and now have an opportunity to attend a workshop in Cambodia this summer in which I will be able to develop my own portfolio.

Here is the project description:

This is an intensive immersion in photography specifically designed for college students or young photographers who have curiosity about the world and wish to make a real advance with their photography and narrative storytelling skills. Like all of VII’s masterclasses and workshops the aim of the program is to launch you into a culturally rich environment and teach you the skills to identify, research and document meaningful stories. Led by renowned VII photojournalists Gary Knight and Anastasia Taylor-Lind, each student will be given an assignment to be tackled individually or in pairs. There are a broad range of subjects which include but are not limited to: floating villages, tourism, spirituality, land mine related issues, primary health care issues, rural life, urbanism, generation x, and arts and crafts. To complete your assignment, you will be engaging in meetings and talks with community leaders—journalists, photographers and NGO workers—who are tackling the big issues that face the country today. At the end of the program you will return home with an edited portfolio and personal journal of this exceptional experience.

What We Need & What You Get

There is a program fee ($4665) which includes all my meals, hotels, transportation when I am in Cambodia. I also have to pay for the plane ticket (~$2,000) to/from Cambodia as well. 

Perks!

I am excited to be able to reward those of you that decide to donate. The things you can get are: a portfolio download, coffee table books, Skype call, a book of my experience that will include field notes & documentation of the journey, and limited edition, archival pigment-prints of various sizes.

The Impact

You are helping me in order to help the world in which we live in. I am very passionate about telling stories and my goal is to use what I learn on this trip to go out into the world and photograph the least of these. You can see previous work I have done from trips in Haiti.

more images at: www.throughHislens.com


Other Ways You Can Help

Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Know any organizations based in Cambodia I can photograph? Contact me!
  • Share this to your friends and family so they can contribute.

If you have any questions, comments, or concerns please feel free to contact me.

info@throughhislens.com

story:
Hi everyone, thanks for reading this!

 

My name is Yvette and I have been a photographer for a few years now. Whilst having started photographing on a film camera, I have worked in several photography studios using both film and digital cameras - and after working for art dealer Linus Carr, my interest in old techniques was sparked. Since then, my digital camera has been gathering dust as my TLR took preference.

 

BUT!

 

Recently, I managed to buy a rather old, and rather large camera (16 x 16") - alas without lens or other materials. Even though I had enough funds to buy the camera and the lens myself (to arrive this week), I could use a hand with gathering the materials needed to actually start creating images with it. It would mean a huge shift in what and how I will photograph things - and I believe it will create a huge leap forward in regards to my work.

 

In sponsoring this project you will not only help me achieve creating unique images within a much shorter time frame, you will help keep an art form alive and even have the oppertunity to own some of the original images created.

 

During the creation of these works, I will make notes/ images on the process and share them with the world. Any processes I find particularly useful will be shared so that everyone will be able to use them.

 

I plan on making Calotypes, Paper negatives and Ambrotypes. I would like to create portraits, both realistic and fantastic, working with models and regular people alike as well as explore parts of my Dutch heritage, either within stillife or landscape images.

 

The funds will go towards:

Board to place underneath the camera, Tripod/ Cart

Portable darkroom tent

Additional Plateholders for this camera (I have 1, the others will have to be custom built)

Trays for development

Chemicals

Chemical bottles for storage of mixed liquids (if applicable)

Protective gloves/ apron

Glass Plates to coat and expose

Paper to expose and develop

Travel

Professional scanning of the best images + archival printing

And ofcourse........

 

postage of these images to my sponsors!

 

If the final target does not get reached, any raised funds will go towards basic materials so I will still be able to get started, and begin documenting the process, which you will be able to follow on my website www.yvettebessels.com.

 

I really appreciate your consideration to help me out (seeing you've read this far down) and would like to thank you in advance if my project is something you'd be willing to sponsor.

 

You'd like to contribute but things are tight? No worries! Spread the word to your family and friends and you can still bask in my eternal gratitude <3

 

 

Any perks will be sent out/ arranged after the fundraising campaign ends
