story:
Richard Kadrey (writer of books and taker of pictures) is teaming up with me (Lela Gwenn writer of stuff and model) to take fun photos Tied up & in Cosplay! 

 

Why? 

 

WHY NOT? 

We are aiming for 4 characters to start with... if we can get to some stretch goals we will add characters! 

 

BUT! To prove this isn't just an exercise in vanity... here's my pledge! If the campaign gets funded I promise to donate 130 hours of the next 12 months to help re-socialize pound puppies and get them ready for their forever homes. 

 

Nerd kink with a heart. Who doesn't love that? 

What characters are on the list???

Cat Woman

Harley Quinn

Leeloo Dallas

Death (Sandman)

Stretch goals! For every $650 past the goal we make... we add a character! 

Kaylee (Firefly)

Doctor Who (genderswap)

Psylocke

Poison Ivy

 

What We Need & What You Get

Well... here we go: 

$2000 covers the creative types 

$1200 covers the costuming

$1050 covers the printing/shipping costs

 

What do you get?

 

Digital Photos,

8x10 singles & Sets,

16x20 poster single & sets,

Calendars,

Soft cover books.

 

Special Opportunities for personalized items & me acting as a "booth babe" at a convention are being offered as well. 

 

Stretch goals! For every $650 past the goal we make... we add a character! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Indiegogo provides share buttons to make it easy for you. I'm also happy to talk to bloggers & podcasters about the project- Leave a comment and I'll get back to you!

 

 

** DUE TO THE ISSUES WE HAVE HAD-- IT MAY BE A LITTLE LONGER THAN PLANNED TO GET YOU ALL THE PICTURES. I WILL KEEP YOU IN THE LOOP!**

story:
Lately the conversation around asylum seekers and refugees in Australia has been a race to the bottom. At times we hear from refugees who have made it to Australia, my photographic project aims to trace it back a step by going to those who have not yet made it and are living in limbo in Indonesia as they await a chance at a better life for them and their families.


While the Abbott Government champions the effectiveness of their 'stop the boats' policy, the conflicts and persecution around the world that people flee from continue unabated.  

Many of these people end up in Indonesia, without legal status, where they now face years of uncertainty as their refugee claims are assessed.

With less boats departing for Australia, and the few that do depart getting turned back, the consequence of the Australian policy is a growing number of asylum seekers living long-term in Indonesia. After paying people smugglers to get to Indonesia, many asylum seekers arrive with little money left.
As processing times blow out under the weight of greater numbers, more and more asylum seekers in Indonesia become entrenched in poverty, without legal access to employment, while organisations that are tasked to provide support do not have the budgets for the growing numbers of people requiring their help. 


Batol Rezayi. June 2014.


Following a brief visit in June, I will be returning to Indonesia in December for six weeks to photograph and tell the stories of those who are most impacted by these policies, yet whose voices have not been part of the conversation. 

The people I met on my first visit were educated, determined and humble. They included a 17 year old Pakistani boy, alone, who taught English to other refugees. A geologist who had worked with the US Army in Afghanistan and was forced to flee as a result. A 28 year-old matriarch who pondered if suicide would help her thirteen and four year old sons have their claims assessed quicker.


Josh's Photo Album. June 2014.


Their stories need telling and their voices need to be heard in the conversation around immigration in Australia, which through the policies of successive governments has lost all sense of humanity. 

An exhibition of the work will be held in Melbourne during July/August 2015, while the photographs and text stories will be viewable online in early 2015. 

To do this though, I need your help.




How You Can Help

Essentially, by donating to the campaign and helping spread the word!
My target is relatively small, and ensures the essentials are covered to get the project completed. 
The biggest expenses will be for accommodation, travel (flights to Indonesia and internal travel) and basic living expenses - i.e. food.
In order to ensure access to the right people and the right places I will be working with a fixer/translator and this means paying them for their work and also ensuring they're well fed too! The role of a fixer is vital to getting the job done. 


I have a series of stretch goals in mind if the initial target is reached, these will include print and greater online outputs for the project to reach a larger audience.
It may also enable me to make a return visit in mid-2015 to check the progress of the people we meet first time around.
These stretch goals will be revealed if we reach the initial target which allows the project to happen. 


Boredom. June, 2014.



The Perks

I've chosen rewards which I can use existing relationships and contacts to produce, knowing that they'll all be of a high quality.

The e-book will include photos from the series, behind the scenes images of the making of the work as well as written articles telling the stories of the people who have been photographed.   

All inkjet prints will be produced by myself in consultation with expert printers, while the chromira prints will be printed at a professional lab. Please note all prints are unframed. You may also swap any prints from this series for any other images of mine from earlier series, that you can see on my website, if availability permits.

All Instax photos will be shot in Indonesia and will be completely one-of-a-kind - nobody else will get the same one as you.

Here's an Instax photo I shot in Jakarta earlier this year as an example of what you might get:



All donors will be invited to a special artists-talk with me in Melbourne when the images are exhibited in early August 2015.

In order to give your donation a second life, I will hold a print auction in mid-2015 of images that I produce thanks to your support with proceeds to go towards a group that works to provide support to refugees.  


About Me

The grandson of German/Latvian immigrants who made numerous failed attempts to leave post-war Germany by boat, I am a Melbourne based photographer with a broad interest in migration based stories.

In 2012/13  I was awarded The Pool Grant which saw me produce a body of work along the Camino De Santiago pilgrim route in Spain. This series was exhibited as part of the Head On photo festival in Sydney in 2013. I have also been a category winner in Capture Magazines 'Australia's Top Emerging Photographers' award and a finalist in the Moran Contemporary Photographic Prize. 

A former student of RMIT's Diploma of Photo-imaging, I am one of two recipients of the 2014-15 graduate in residence which provides me with non-financial material support for this project. 

Over the past two years I have also worked as a lecturer as part of RMIT's Cert IV and Diploma of Photo-Imaging, along with working within some of RMIT's photography short courses.

Bourke St Mall. 2010. 


Unemployee Of The Year. Spain 2012.



Fire Bull. Spain 2012.




Risks & Challenges

One of the major challenges with this sort of work is in building relationships and trust with people for them to be comfortable with sharing their story with you.

Having already made an initial visit for a week in June I have contacts who will help introduce me to more people whose stories can be told. The six week time frame of this project also allows me to make multiple visits to people and build a stronger rapport with them.



Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute but would still like to help there's a number of ways you can do so.
Share this page with your friends, families and colleagues through social media and email.
Follow me in Indonesia via instagram, from early december.
But most importantly, have the conversation with everyone you meet and ask them what they would do if they were forced to give up everything and flee the threat of torture and death.
story_txt:
Lately the conversation around asylum seekers and refugees in Australia has been a race to the bottom. At times we hear from refugees who have made it to Australia, my photographic project aims to trace it back a step by going to those who have not yet made it and are living in limbo in Indonesia as they await a chance at a better life for them and their families.
While the Abbott Government champions the effectiveness of their 'stop the boats' policy, the conflicts and persecution around the world that people flee from continue unabated.  Many of these people end up in Indonesia, without legal status, where they now face years of uncertainty as their refugee claims are assessed. With less boats departing for Australia, and the few that do depart getting turned back, the consequence of the Australian policy is a growing number of asylum seekers living long-term in Indonesia. After paying people smugglers to get to Indonesia, many asylum seekers arrive with little money left. As processing times blow out under the weight of greater numbers, more and more asylum seekers in Indonesia become entrenched in poverty, without legal access to employment, while organisations that are tasked to provide support do not have the budgets for the growing numbers of people requiring their help. 

Batol Rezayi. June 2014.
Following a brief visit in June, I will be returning to Indonesia in December for six weeks to photograph and tell the stories of those who are most impacted by these policies, yet whose voices have not been part of the conversation. The people I met on my first visit were educated, determined and humble. They included a 17 year old Pakistani boy, alone, who taught English to other refugees. A geologist who had worked with the US Army in Afghanistan and was forced to flee as a result. A 28 year-old matriarch who pondered if suicide would help her thirteen and four year old sons have their claims assessed quicker.Josh's Photo Album. June 2014.
Their stories need telling and their voices need to be heard in the conversation around immigration in Australia, which through the policies of successive governments has lost all sense of humanity. An exhibition of the work will be held in Melbourne during July/August 2015, while the photographs and text stories will be viewable online in early 2015. To do this though, I need your help.

How You Can Help
Essentially, by donating to the campaign and helping spread the word!My target is relatively small, and ensures the essentials are covered to get the project completed. The biggest expenses will be for accommodation, travel (flights to Indonesia and internal travel) and basic living expenses - i.e. food. In order to ensure access to the right people and the right places I will be working with a fixer/translator and this means paying them for their work and also ensuring they're well fed too! The role of a fixer is vital to getting the job done. 
I have a series of stretch goals in mind if the initial target is reached, these will include print and greater online outputs for the project to reach a larger audience. It may also enable me to make a return visit in mid-2015 to check the progress of the people we meet first time around. These stretch goals will be revealed if we reach the initial target which allows the project to happen. 
Boredom. June, 2014.


The PerksI've chosen rewards which I can use existing relationships and contacts to produce, knowing that they'll all be of a high quality. The e-book will include photos from the series, behind the scenes images of the making of the work as well as written articles telling the stories of the people who have been photographed.   All inkjet prints will be produced by myself in consultation with expert printers, while the chromira prints will be printed at a professional lab. Please note all prints are unframed. You may also swap any prints from this series for any other images of mine from earlier series, that you can see on my website, if availability permits.All Instax photos will be shot in Indonesia and will be completely one-of-a-kind - nobody else will get the same one as you.Here's an Instax photo I shot in Jakarta earlier this year as an example of what you might get:


All donors will be invited to a special artists-talk with me in Melbourne when the images are exhibited in early August 2015.In order to give your donation a second life, I will hold a print auction in mid-2015 of images that I produce thanks to your support with proceeds to go towards a group that works to provide support to refugees.  
 

About Me

The grandson of German/Latvian immigrants who made numerous failed attempts to leave post-war Germany by boat, I am a Melbourne based photographer with a broad interest in migration based stories. In 2012/13  I was awarded The Pool Grant which saw me produce a body of work along the Camino De Santiago pilgrim route in Spain. This series was exhibited as part of the Head On photo festival in Sydney in 2013. I have also been a category winner in Capture Magazines 'Australia's Top Emerging Photographers' award and a finalist in the Moran Contemporary Photographic Prize. A former student of RMIT's Diploma of Photo-imaging, I am one of two recipients of the 2014-15 graduate in residence which provides me with non-financial material support for this project. Over the past two years I have also worked as a lecturer as part of RMIT's Cert IV and Diploma of Photo-Imaging, along with working within some of RMIT's photography short courses.

Bourke St Mall. 2010. 
Unemployee Of The Year. Spain 2012.

Fire Bull. Spain 2012.




Risks & Challenges

One of the major challenges with this sort of work is in building relationships and trust with people for them to be comfortable with sharing their story with you.
Having already made an initial visit for a week in June I have contacts who will help introduce me to more people whose stories can be told. The six week time frame of this project also allows me to make multiple visits to people and build a stronger rapport with them.

Other Ways You Can Help

 If you are unable to contribute but would still like to help there's a number of ways you can do so. Share this page with your friends, families and colleagues through social media and email. Follow me in Indonesia via instagram, from early december.But most importantly, have the conversation with everyone you meet and ask them what they would do if they were forced to give up everything and flee the threat of torture and death.

story:
Worum geht’s hier eigentlich?

Einige haben es mitbekommen, für andere ist es komplett neu, aber im Jahr 2016 habe ich erfolgreich mein erstes Buch Snapshot Stories durch diese Plattform finanzieren lassen. Nach unglaublich gutem Feedback, fünf Ausstellungen, Radiointerviews und einem Arte Tracks Beitrag zu dem Buch und meiner Selbst (erscheint Ende des Jahres) ist die logische Schlussfolgerung: weiter machen.

Was macht man aber wenn die Erwartungen jetzt so hoch sind? Beinahe täglich gingen neue Nachrichten in meinem Postfach ein in denen ich Lob, Kritik aber auch Dankbarkeit dafür erfahren konnte, dass ich verstorbene Familienmitglieder mit ins Buch aufgenommen habe und somit eine Plattform der Verarbeitung geschaffen habe. Das erhöht natürlich den Druck und auch die Erwartung, die ich an mich selbst stelle.

Es wird kein zweiter Teil von Snapshot Stories werden, den wird und kann es auch nie geben. Das Buch hat in seiner Geschichte einen Zeitraum von 12 Jahren abgedeckt. Mein Leben hat sich seitdem geändert: Ich lebe in Deutschland, habe mittlerweile ein Kind und alles hat sich relativ "normalisiert". Zumindest so normal, wie es in meiner Realität werden kann. Dennoch ist das kein Grund aufzuhören, sondern weiterzumachen.

Das kommende Buch wird den Titel Zwei Null Eins Sieben tragen. Der Name ist allerdings eine Lüge denn es trägt den Titel nur, weil es 2017 rauskommt, sich aber keinesfalls auf dieses eine Jahr beschränken wird sondern ungefähr 2014 oder 2015 losgeht.

Neben ein paar Bildern aus Amerika wird es diesmal auch in die Hood von Jamaica gehen, und auch das Leben auf den Philippinen zeigen. Auch Deutschland wird nicht zu kurz kommen: exklusive Einblicke in die ‪187 Strassenbande und quer durch Deutschland mit Rapper ‪Estikay. Wie auch schon bei Snapshot Stories werden die Geschichten zu den jeweiligen Bildern erzählt.

Das Buch ist weit davon entfernt fertig zu sein. Das Jahr läuft ja auch noch ein wenig und ich möchte bis Dezember noch möglichst viel mitnehmen beziehungsweise aufnehmen (und noch die ein oder andere Reise machen). Somit ist es schwer einzuschätzen, welchen Umfang das ganze haben wird aber es wird mindestens genauso viel Content wie Snapshot Stories besitzen – mindestens 228 Seiten.

Ihr könnt mir helfen die Kosten für den Druck zu decken, indem ihr euer Exemplar des Buches Zwei Null Eins Sieben vorbestellt. Der Vorteil für dich, wenn du das Buch jetzt schon vorbestellst ist, dass du es für 30 Euro bekommst – später wird es 40 Euro kosten. Außerdem werde ich wieder alles dafür tun, dass ihr das Buch noch vor Weihnachten in der Hand halten könnt. Der offizielle Release-Termin für alle, die nach dem Crowdfunding bestellen, ist Mitte Januar 2017.


Wer bist du überhaupt?

Pascal Kerouche, Fotograf und aktuell lebe ich in Hamburg. Meine sonstigen Arbeiten könnt ihr euch auf pascalkerouche.com anschauen, oder auch einfach meinen Boy Meets World Blog besuchen – und ja, er hieß schon bevor Drake seine 2017 Tour angekündigt hat, so.

Im Juni 2016 hat außerdem das fotoMAGAZIN ein sehr schönes Interview mit mir veröffentlicht, und ich denke, dass dort ein guter Eindruck vermittelt wird, wer ich eigentlich bin. Darum halte ich mich an dieser Stelle kurz und wenn ihr möchtet, könnt ihr es euch einfach hier anschauen.


Preview? Klar!




Wie sehen denn die Perks aus? Also das Poster oder der Donner Eulen Hoodie?

Wie sehen denn die Perks aus? Also das Poster oder der Donner Eulen Hoodie?

story:
Nomuka Island, Kingdom of Tonga

In the spring of 2016 I spent six weeks documenting daily life and taking family portraits of the inhabitants of the small island of Nomuka. I’m raising money to send printed portraits back to each family and a 100+ page printed book that contains a mixture of documentary images and all the family portraits.

 

About Me

My name is David Clumpner and I am a photographer from Montana in the US.  I served in the Peace Corps in Palau, a small island in the western Pacific in the early 2000s. During my years there I became interested in creating a printed record of the families who inhabit small islands, as they often have little to no means to create this for themselves. This is the third iteration of this project (previously Palau and Okinawa) but the first to include documentary imagery of daily life and a printed book.

 

About Nomuka

Nomuka is a very small island at the southern end of the Ha'apai Island Group in central Tonga.  About 400 residents live on the island, which is a six-hour ferry ride from the capital, Nuku'alofa.  Religion is a very important element of the culture, with seven churches on the island and up to six services/week depending on your denomination. There is only electricity for six hours a day and very few residents have computers or cameras. Women weave very time-intensive mats made from dried pandanus to sell to Tongans living in the capital or abroad while men spend much of their time growing and collecting food. The kids attend one of two primary schools or the Methodist high school, then after class they fly homemade kites around the village.

 

Why This Project is Important

Nomukans have smartphones but no way of backing up their photos.  The environmental conditions in the tropics can be fierce on electronics, so it's common for a phone to die and take its memory with it.  For this reason and the speed with which our society moves to new forms of digital media, I believe strongly in printed photos as the best form of passing memories down to future generations.  During my six weeks on Nomuka I photographed nearly every family on the island (70+ portraits).  Each family will receive two 8x10 laminated (to protect against humidity) enlargements and about ten 4x6 prints to share with family and friends.

I did an Indiegogo campaign for my previous family portrait project on Angaur, Palau a few years ago.  About six months after mailing the family portraits I got word of an accident where three men overturned their fishing boat and were swept out to sea.  A few months later I received this message from the widow, whose only visual memory of her husband was in the family portrait I sent her: "Am so glad for your great efforts for your project. Seriously if not, I don't have the best family portrait, something I will treasure for me & esp our kids. Once again, thank you & hope you"ll visit Palau in the future."

This message solidified the importance of family portraits and inspired me to continue this project to at least one more island (but hopefully more!).

 

What We Need and What You Get

My goal is to send 100 books and 80 family portrait packages to Nomuka.  Some of the extra books will go to the school libraries and the few families who opted not to have their portraits taken.  The book is softcover and is comprised of about 85 pages of documentary photos showing life on Nomuka and 15 pages of the family and school portraits.  150 books will cost $2975 and the prints I hope to send will cost approximately $650.  My best guess on the shipping expenses is about $900 to get everything to Tonga.  The remaining amount will be spent on miscellaneous expenses like a graphic designer (to make maps for the book) and laminating sheets.  If we beat the goal I would like to send more laminated photos back as I have about 1000 of them in my collection that didn't make the book but would still be wonderful to deliver.  If we REALLY beat the goal, I have some English-language teaching material requests from the schools that would be great to fulfill!

If you contribute at a higher level perk, both you and a family will get a book and the family will also receive a print package.  I should be able to include a copy of a photo of the family you have supported, too!  If you would like to gift a contribution on someone else's behalf, just let me know and I will include a note thanking that person for their contribution. 

There will only be ten limited edition books so if you think I'm going to be famous or you just really want to support this project, this is a great contribution level!  And you also get a bottle of vanilla extract made (by me!) from vanilla beans I bought in Tonga.

Thank you so much to those who have sponsored the project so far with in-kind donations: MagMod Lighting Modifiers, Fundy Software (which I used to design the book!), and Brown Publishing from Portland, Oregon.

Here are a few more photos from the project:

story:
ESPAÑOL__________________________

Mi nombre es María Gabriela Chirinos, soy Arquitecto y Fotógrafo.

Necesito tu colaboración para ayudarme a cubrir los costos de viaje y estadía para representar a Venezuela en el Premio Internacional Arte Laguna en la categoría Arte Fotográfico, en la ciudad de Venecia desde el 25 de marzo al 9 de abril.

Soy la Primera venezolana en participar en este prestigioso Premio, el cuál este año realizará su 11va. edición. Fuí seleccionada entre más de 1100 fotógrafos participantes en el Premio Arte Laguna  y luego de una exhaustiva revisión por el Jurado, solo 30 artistas de cada categoría estaremos exponiendo nuestras Obras en la Final en el L'Arsenale de Venecia.

Si me ayudas estarás colaborando a fomentar el desarrollo cultural de nuestro País, apalancándome para poder estar presente en tan relevante evento.

La recaudación de fondos estará destinada a complementar los gastos concernientes a Impresiones, montaje, empaque y envío de la Obra así como para costos de pasaje, estadía y alimentación durante los 17 días que debo participar en el evento, tanto en la Inauguración como en las charlas y visitas guiadas posteriores.

Cada aporte solidario sumará y entre todos podremos cumplir la meta de tener a Venezuela presente por primera vez en tan prestigioso evento de Arte.

Mil graciassssssss por sumarte!

__________________________________________________________________________

ENGLISH__________________________

My name is María Gabriela Chirinos, I am Architect and Photographer.

I need your collaboration to help me cover the costs of traveling and staying to represent Venezuela in the International Arte Laguna Prize in the Photographic Art category, in the city of Venice from March 25th to April 9th.

I am the First Venezuelan to participate in this prestigious Prize, which this year will make its 11th. edition. I was selected among more than 1100 photographers participating in the Arte Laguna Prize and after an exhaustive review by the Jury, only 30 artists from each category will be exhibiting our Works in the Final at L'Arsenale in Venice.

If you help me you will be collaborating to foment the cultural development of our Country, leveraging me to be present in such a relevant event.

The collection of funds will be destined to complement the expenses related to Impressions, assembly, packing and delivery of the Work as well as for costs of passage, stay and food during the 17 days that I must participate in the event, both in the Inauguration and in the Talks and guided tours later.

Each solidarity contribution will add and among all we will be able to fulfill the goal of having Venezuela present for the first time in this prestigious Art event.

Thank you for adding you!

story:
Lumo offers lots of experiences, knowledge and possibilities to improve skills as a nature photographer. Or just to enjoy interesting stories and outstanding images. All topics from all continents featuring the top nature photographers of the world! 100 pages 6 times a year.

Lumo is a Scandinavian nature photography magazine that focuses strongly on northern nature. Lumo is made in Finland and Finnish nature photographers are featured in each issue. Lumo highlights the nature of taiga forests, but also handles topics from around the world from underwater to the mountain top and from desert to tropical rainforest.
English Lumo is an e-magazine that is based on a Finnish Lumo that comes out as a print and an e-magazine. First issue of Finnish Lumo came out in March 2015. The first issue of English edition is already published. It is downloadable for free for Apple and Android tablets in App Store and Google Play. Additionally English Lumo is available as an online magazine to be read with a portable and a desktop computer. In the future the single issues of online magazine will be available in Lumos' web store:
Lumo web store

Allthough the main focus is on northern and arctic nature and wildlife, we gather current and diverse compilation of topics around the world for those interested in nature and photography. With this recipe comes out a fascinating combination that you won’t find anywhere else.
Nature photographs are not always cute. We go outside the comfort zone and emphasize important role of nature photography by featuring poaching, illegal wildlife trade and environmental disasters.
There isn’t a large media house behind Lumo. Therefore we need your help in the beginning of our journey. Lumo Publishing Ltd is owned by us, the workers of the company, by one hundred percent. We work without counting hours and yes, we love it. And hope that you will too! Our goal is to raise 5000 dollars. All money gathered is used for generating English Lumo and developing its availability.

Co-founders of Lumo are Raisa Tasanto, Jukka Palm and Jussi Leppänen. We are all experienced professionals of nature photography journalism and passionate nature lovers. Large group of nature photographers around the world works with us to make Lumo an outstanding magazine. We have a good number of collaborators and partners, for example Finnature, WWF Finland and Hannu Hautala Nature Photography Centre, and we seek all the time more. Our contributors among others are Peter Cairns, Markus Varesvuo, Lassi Rautiainen, Jukka Lehtonen, Jouni Klinga and Marina Cano.

In each issue we have enrichments such as videos and galleries to bring the enchanting wildlife more closer to you. Enchanting is actually what Lumo means. In Finnish language it means enchantment, charm, captivating or almost magical. On the other hand Lu Mo is an abbreviation used in nature science etc. of the words luonnon monimuotoisuus that means biodiversity.


All our contributors, the permanent and the ones featuring once in a while, are extremely important to us. We want to and will keep good relationships to each of our collaborators and partners. Fair contracts are the cornerstone of our operations.

Get enchanted and fund us! Get your own Lumo for 33 dollars per year!
Read more about the Finnish owlman Jari Peltomäki in English Lumo 1. You can find the online edition here and enjoy it free:
English Lumo 1

Show your support also by telling a friend and following us in social media. Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Please, use also the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Lumo offers lots of experiences, knowledge and possibilities to improve skills
as a nature photographer. Or just to enjoy interesting stories and outstanding
images. All topics from all continents featuring the top nature photographers
of the world! 100 pages 6 times a year.
Lumo is a Scandinavian nature photography magazine that focuses strongly
on northern nature. Lumo is made in Finland and Finnish nature photographers
are featured in each issue. Lumo highlights the nature of taiga forests, but
also handles topics from around the world from underwater to the mountain top
and from desert to tropical rainforest.English Lumo is an e-magazine that is based on a Finnish Lumo that comes
out as a print and an e-magazine. First issue of Finnish Lumo came out in March
2015. The first issue of English edition
is already published. It is downloadable for free for Apple and Android tablets in App Store
and Google Play. Additionally English Lumo is available as an online magazine to be read with a portable and a desktop computer. In the future the single issues of online magazine will be available in Lumos' web store:Lumo web store
Allthough the main focus is on northern and arctic nature and wildlife, we
gather current and diverse compilation of topics around the world for those
interested in nature and photography. With this recipe comes out a fascinating combination that you won’t find anywhere else.Nature photographs are not always cute. We go
outside the comfort zone and emphasize important role of nature photography by
featuring poaching, illegal wildlife trade and environmental disasters.There isn’t a large media house behind Lumo. Therefore
we need your help in the beginning of our journey. Lumo Publishing Ltd is owned
by us, the workers of the company, by one hundred percent. We work without counting
hours and yes, we love it. And hope that you will too! Our goal is to
raise 5000 dollars. All money gathered
is used for generating English Lumo and developing its availability.

story:
The Project


Help us frame our exhibition on Beauty Shop Culture! I am an award-winning photographer, author (Counter Culture: The American Coffee Shop Waitress) and owner of Taylor Made Culture (www.taylormadeculture.com). We produce multimedia projects that document various aspects of American culture. The Beauty Shop Culture exhibition features longstanding salons that have served communities for decades. It celebrates multiculturalism and promotes a greater understanding and appreciation for our cultural differences. Although there have been studies of barbershop culture, the beauty shop has been comparatively overlooked. This visual anthropology project will examine all aspects of the beauty salon as a cultural institution, including its role in developing and maintaining community. The exhibition with eventually travel throughout the United States.


What We Need

We are so close! We have received 2 grants to document the salons and now we are seeking funding to frame the exhibition so it can tour the US. There are a total of 40 images, ten at 20 x 30 inches and thirty at 13 x 19 inches. Each image will cost approximately $120 to frame ($120 x 40 = 4800). If we don't reach our funding goal, we will frame as many photographs as possible.


What You Get

Pledge $1 or more

We will keep you posted about any new developments with Taylor Made Culture projects


Pledge $25 or more

Project updates plus a 8x11 inch signed print of your choice.


Pledge $50 or more

Project updates plus a signed copy of my book, Counter Culture: The American Coffee Shop Waitress. http://www.powells.com/biblio/1-9780801474408-0


Pledge $100 or more

Project updates plus one 13x19 inch signed print of your choice and a signed copy of the book Counter Culture: The American Coffee Shop Waitress - http://www.powells.com/biblio/1-9780801474408-0


Pledge $500 or more

Project updates plus two 13x19 inch signed print of your choice, a 5-minute DVD of the waitress project and two signed copies of the book Counter Culture: The American Coffee Shop Waitress - http://www.powells.com/biblio/1-9780801474408-0


Other Ways You Can Help

(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)

story:
Balancing Rocks - eBook & photo Book about inspirational photos

‘Balancing Rocks’ is an ongoing project since 2011. It's about photographing unusual and unforgettable stone sculptures that are forcing you to capture them with your camera. I was attracted to the shapes and ambient back in 2011 when I've first seen them. Balanced stones that amazingly defy wind sometimes last for just a few days at a time days before collapsing. The incredible story to be told of how the sculptures were created is a story to be told in the future and it will include you if you choose to participate by becoming involved in this campaign in any way that you choose.


                     



Similar artwork can be found at other locations. I've found reports of them in Australia, US, Canada and other countries as well.


                     



I've accepted the challenge of photographing these sculptures and to eventually create a website where the photos will be available. I want to photograph the summer season with indigenous artists in the southern hemisphere and the trip itself is to take place in the summer of 2014 if everything goes as planed.


Artists and painters have expressed interest in contributing to the creative presentation of this project and thanks to them there are a few very unique limited edition perks available.


                     



You can help this project by either donating or just talking about it on the internet with your friends and family. I welcome anyone who is willing to help and support this cause in any way he or she can.


What do I need

I have a classic photographic equipment. For a project I need a professional digital camera, lenses and accessories, professional development and layout of the website.

I need your help to fund a professional digital photographic equipment, dedicated website, photo editing and traveling expenses. I think I can do it for a minimum of about $70,000 - anything less would mean I would have to cut corners on my plans for the 2014. I hope in raising more so that I could buy video equipment and make a documented movie about my photo journey to Australia and US in 2014 if everything goes well. I am funding this from the sales of calendars, photo prints and hopefully your donations. Part of the funds raised will go to artists for their work.


What do you get

Everybody receives access to private Facebook group. Members in the private FB group will participate in the making of the photo book with voting on the photos that they think should be included in the photo book, and the overall layout. My intention is that we make a short representation of this form of art together with my supporters.  

I've tried to include something for everyone so you can choose your perk from T-shirt, edited photo posters, authentic hand drawn illustrations and authentic graphics drawings black&white style,  unique acrylic paint on canvas, unique oil paint on canvas, etc.

Hand drawn illustrations and canvas paintings have the cost of custom framing included.


If you would like to suggest any other perk please let me know via Twitter, Facebook fan page, private Facebook group page or post comment on Indiegogo comments page.


The Funding

What the funds will be used for:

  • The cost of perks

  • Shipping expenses

  • The cost of traveling

  • New photo equipment

  • And other expenses


                     


Risks And Challenges

As with most things in life, unforeseeable obstacles and setbacks may come up. Although I plan to have the book completed by mid-April. If any issues should arise I promise to post updates.



About Myself

I've been working in the field of professional photography for the past 40 years, I started when I was 11 years old in my grandfathers photo lab. My grandfather was a professional photographer his whole life so it makes sense that I'am continuing the family tradition.

Embedded in the classic photography as a follower, I was dismissive of digital photography. With digital photography it's a challenge to achieve natural effects, without any digital processing. The current digital photographic equipment can take advantage of the years of knowledge of classical photography and transferred to a digital format. Especially interesting is the study because of the special and unusual lighting conditions at sea. My focus is always about unusual and interesting events in nature or in public events.


Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Share this campaign with your friends on facebook, twitter or send to your email contacts who you think might be interested in this project.

The Indiegogo share tools on this site can help get the word out!

Thank you so much for your support!


                     


What you can do to help now:

  • Pick your favorite perk and donate to help us reach the goal.

  • Tweet about why you donated to the campaign.

  • Tweet about why you're excited about the campaign, even if you can't donate.

  • Email your friends who might be interested asking if they can donate too.  

  • Like this campaign on Facebook.

  • Click +1 on Google Plus.

story:
CAMPAIGN-END DISCOUNTS!

Retouching half-off! 1 hour for $50 or half-hour for $25! Headshots for $150, milestone portraits for $500! NEW PERK: Photoshop tutoring!



A Photographer Without a Camera is Like Mashed Potatoes Without Gravy

Do you want to live in a world with dry potatoes? I don't.

Hi.

I'm Alice Hanners.

You've been invited here today for a single purpose: help me fill the void left by my stolen camera.

I pinched pennies and saved to afford my gorgeous camera in my final year at University. I used it to photograph the images you see above (and below). My goal was to create large-scale prints that captured the beauty of pre-Raphaelite painters. (For more on this, scroll down to the almost-end!)

That camera was good to me, and I have no doubt that it would have been with me for much longer.  But it was not to be. 

This past summer, my apartment was invaded by workers from the building, eager to "renovate". One wobbly toilet, three wall gouges, swapped hot-and-cold-water pipes and several broken lightbulbs later, I now have a "renovated" apartment--and no camera.

I live in New York City, the most expensive city in the US, working as a photo editor. I'm lucky to have a job at all, with an arts degree, (it was between art school or an English degree, I decided to be practical), and I've gotten by via freelance projects on the side.

I can't moonlight as a photographer if I don't have a camera. I can't shoot engagement photos, headshots, portraits, or my holiday card featuring my cats wearing adorable Christmas collars. You don't understand, they're so cute.

If I can't shoot, I can't afford to replace my camera.

That's where you come in.

What I Need & What You Get

I need a camera. Cameras can be bought at any price point, which is how I know that every penny of this campaign will go to good use. The goal is based on my dream camera, the Mark II (and a nice lens). I work a lot in low light and I've been dreaming of this camera for years. Importantly, the more this campaign raises, the nicer the camera/lenses I can buy, and as a result, the better my photos will be. This matters to you because you (yes, you!) can star in one of my photographs!  

So, I need a camera--but you need things, too, and I want you to get something for your money.  There are many levels of perks. If you contribute even a single dollar, it brings me that much closer to my goal. Fans and contributors will be updated on EVERYTHING I do with my camera (well, maybe not everything).

First up are my beautiful 5"x7" postcards. 


These are designed to fit USPS regulations (you can actually mail them! in the mail! old school!) and feature a full-color, UV-protected reproduction of my pre-Raphaelite works. Buy 1 for $5 or 10 for $35, or--there are a whole bunch of packages. Check them out on the right.

Here are the images featured on the postcards!

Echo & Narcissus (modeled by Carolyn Bauch and Matthew Mazur):


Romeo & Juliet (modeled by Sanders Schneider and Jacqueline Jacob):


Rapunzel (modeled by Elena Zachary):


Cupid & Psyche (modeled by Ryan Thon and Kate Roberts):


Cinderella (modeled by Eden Palmer, with Hansen Donius as Prince Charming):


Red Riding Hood (modeled by Courtney Brown):


Pandora (modeled by Carolyn Bauch):


Ophelia (modeled by Alina Cepulis):


Prometheus (modeled by Nicholas Clark):


Persephone (modeled by Calista Merritt):


BUT WAIT! THERE'S MORE!

Next, we've got photoshoots! Whether you need a headshot, an engagement photo, a family portrait, or if you want to pose as Zeus hurling lightning from a cloud bank, all things are possible with perks!

Check out the options to your right. Don't see something you want? Feel free to contact me and let me know what you're thinking. By succeeding with this campaign, it means that I can take all kinds of photographs for all kind of people, reasons, and prices. 

Headshots include the basics. Hair/makeup not included, though I can (and will) touch you up as needed. I know nothing about styling men's hair. Don't even ask. Images will be retouched to your satisfaction (within reason). Bring any wardrobe changes you want. Whether you're updating your decade-old 8x10 or if it's your first time, I'll be gentle and understanding, and work with you at your own pace to get great photos.

You may notice that a milestone photo (engagement/wedding/family/pregnancy portrait, etc.) costs significantly more than a headshot. This perk is for when you want something just a much more special than a standard portrait. It will be personal, beautiful, and just what you want. I approach my portraits with the idea that they will be as beloved and treasured as, say, a painted family portrait, passed down through the generations.  While it will not be a production on the scale of a more elaborate pre-Raphaelite photo, these photos can include themes, sets, etc., within reason. Steampunk engagement photos! Dramatic, Vogue-esque new baby photos! (Is there such thing as an old baby?) This package is very unique in the fact that you will receive digital copies for reproducing these images (for your own personal use only--as wedding invitations, backup prints, etc.). This is your image for life!

Pre-Raphaelite photos are much more involved, both before and after the shoot. For these photos, I will work with you to provide and/or supplement wardrobe, props, and sets. The style, story, and location will be researched thoroughly prior to the shoot. Poses will be mapped out, storyboards drawn and locations perfected. The complexity of my initial photos increased with my experience, and I will continue that. An estimated 30-40 hours of retouching will go into each final photo. Creative decisions are ultimately my own--with this perk, I am pledging to deliver a stunning, beautiful photograph, so you're going to have to trust me. You will not receive a digital copy of the image(s), but you will have the opportunity to receive your print at whatever size you choose, up to 6', for only the additional material cost of printing.

"I want to purchase a photo perk but I can't do it before March 28th! Why are you discriminating against the date-challenged?!"

Hey, man, hey! Chill! Send me a message (contact user) and let's talk it out, yeah? I'm sure we can solve this challenge.

 NOW OFFERING PRINTS!

As requested, you can now purchase prints! Photos will be printed on velvety-soft, archival matte paper. Since my photos vary quite a bit in their dimensions, the title and blank paper will fill in for the odd sizes. Persephone, for example, will be exactly 11"x14" and will not feature a title. Please contact me if you would like the image smaller and a title added!

For odd sizes, the image will appear similarly to this:



"Why Do YOU Deserve My Money?"

Great question.

I could give you a sob story about how I need a camera to make money to pay for my cats' vet bills. I could not-so-subtly work it into my campaign text by saying "I could give you a sob story about--"

Look, only you can decide if my cause is worth your money. So for my part, I'm trying to give you your money's worth; you have my gratitude if you contribute, but you deserve more than gratitude. You're helping me when I need it most, and I want to give back. The postcards are a way for me to do that on a smaller scale, while representing my work and giving you something you can use and admire. The other perks are things that I can give back, things that maybe you can't buy in a store. Who else would you turn to for a portrait of you and your six brothers as the seven dwarves? No, don't tell me, I hate competition.

"What Happens If You Don't Meet Your Goal?"

It sucks. But not for you. 

The cheapest decent DSLR on the market is about $500. If I make less than that, I will borrow/rent a camera to complete any photo perks that have been purchased. If I make more than that, I will buy the best camera & lenses that I can afford, and leftover will go toward accessories (memory cards, batteries) and future photography projects. Not a single cent of your money will be wasted. All perks will be fulfilled, all postcards shipped. Do you trust me? Then hop on my magic carpet.

Other Ways You Can Help

Got no money? Boy, can I relate. Help me out by sharing this with your friends. Share with your coworkers. Your followers.  Your parents. Your pets. Whether they're actors who need headshots or postcard enthusiasts or fans of Caravaggio and Waterhouse, tell everyone--spread the word and help me reach my goal.  It will make all of my dreams come true. Well, not the ones where I'm flying or can teleport.


"This is so long, do I have to keep reading?" Not unless you want to (or are non-US/Canada)! Here's bonus information on my pre-Raphaelite project.


More About the Pre-Raphaelite-Inspired Photos

Though I can draw decently well, I've never been able to wield a paintbrush. What do you do when your favorite artists don't work in your preferred medium? You fake it, of course.

My goal was to create rich, beautiful images that felt like paintings, but didn't use artificial brushstrokes or other such gimmicks.

One of my favorite aspects of the pre-Raphaelite style was their commitment to storytelling. Growing up, I listed greek myths and fairy tales among my favorites, and once I was old enough to understand it, I added Shakespeare. These are classic tales, recognizable by most people, young or old--but even if you don't know who the figures are, I needed the story to be told on its own.

So I needed the composition, the lighting, the subject matter, to all hearken back to the pre-Raphaelite masters. And they had to be BIG. Romeo & Juliet ended up being 3'x6' once printed, set in a gorgeous, ornate frame that weighed approximately four tons. Check out the final show here. Placards are 4"x5" for scale.

There were hits and there were misses, mostly due to time and budget constraints, and sometimes the weather. 'Persephone' ended up not including a giant chasm in the earth because, well, nobody would lend me an industrial excavator.  As a result, the story isn't obvious at first glance.

There were serendipitous moments, though, mixed with hard work; one of my professors had a stream running through her backyard, and with a bit of digging and dam-building, we had a pond perfect for 'Echo and Narcissus'. Take a peek at Narcissus' reflection and you'll see Echo's in the water as well. Nice.

In the end, after two years of research and hard work, I had 10 beautiful images that I was proud of. I'd learned to work with a hairpin budget and a mid-level camera to create photos that could be printed on a grand scale. I saw potential in every face I came across; not a single person in these photos is a professional model, they were all my fellow students.

I would love to continue this project.  Whether or not any of the pre-Raphaelite perks are purchased, if this project is funded I intend to create more of these images and will update anyone who contributed to this campaign.





***INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING*** 

Look, I don't want to profit off of the distance between us. If you're not located in the US, please calculate shipping costs for your perk and add that to your contribution. If you don't add the correct amount, you'll have the option to pay the remainder before I ship it out. 

How to calculate rates, using the USPS shipping calculator: 

  • 1 Postcard: Select "letter" and choose weight of 1oz, and select "letter" again for the second option. 
  • 2 Postcards: Select "letter" and choose weight of 1oz, and select "letter" again for the second option.
  • 5 Postcards: Select "large envelope" and choose weight of 2oz, and select "rigid" on the second page. 
  • 10 Postcards: Select "large envelope" and choose weight of 4oz, and select "rigid" and "over 1/4" thickness" on the second page. 
  • 100 Postcards: Select "package" and choose weight of 30oz. Depending on your location, it may be cheaper to select "Priority Mail International Large Video Flat Rate priced box". 
  • View "First-Class International Options" for (usually) the cheapest price. You may request a different shipping method if you add the correct amount. 
  • PLEASE CONTACT ME BEFORE SELECTING A PHOTOSHOOT PERK IF YOU ARE NON-US/CANADA.

(For more on this, scroll down to the almost-end!)That camera was good to me, and I have no doubt that it would have been with me for much longer.  But it was not to be. This past summer, my apartment was invaded by workers from the building, eager to "renovate". One wobbly toilet, three wall gouges, swapped hot-and-cold-water pipes and several broken lightbulbs later, I now have a "renovated" apartment--and no camera.I live in New York City, the most expensive city in the US, working as a photo editor. I'm lucky to have a job at all, with an arts degree, (it was between art school or an English degree, I decided to be practical), and I've gotten by via freelance projects on the side.I can't moonlight as a photographer if I don't have a camera. I can't shoot engagement photos, headshots, portraits, or my holiday card featuring my cats wearing adorable Christmas collars. You don't understand, they're so cute.If I can't shoot, I can't afford to replace my camera.That's where you come in.What I Need & What You GetI need a camera. Cameras can be bought at any price point, which is how I know that every penny of this campaign will go to good use. The goal is based on my dream camera, the Mark II (and a nice lens). I work a lot in low light and I've been dreaming of this camera for years. Importantly, the more this campaign raises, the nicer the camera/lenses I can buy, and as a result, the better my photos will be. This matters to you because you (yes, you!) can star in one of my photographs!  So, I need a camera--but you need things, too, and I want you to get something for your money.  There are many levels of perks. If you contribute even a single dollar, it brings me that much closer to my goal. Fans and contributors will be updated on EVERYTHING I do with my camera (well, maybe not everything).First up are my beautiful 5"x7" postcards. 
These are designed to fit USPS regulations (you can actually mail them! in the mail! old school!) and feature a full-color, UV-protected reproduction of my pre-Raphaelite works. Buy 1 for $5 or 10 for $35, or--there are a whole bunch of packages. Check them out on the right.




Here are the images featured on the postcards!
Echo & Narcissus (modeled by Carolyn Bauch and Matthew Mazur):





Romeo & Juliet (modeled by Sanders Schneider and Jacqueline Jacob):





Rapunzel (modeled by Elena Zachary):






Cupid & Psyche (modeled by Ryan Thon and Kate Roberts):



Cinderella (modeled by Eden Palmer, with Hansen Donius as Prince Charming):




Red Riding Hood (modeled by Courtney Brown):






Pandora (modeled by Carolyn Bauch):






Ophelia (modeled by Alina Cepulis):





Prometheus (modeled by Nicholas Clark):






Persephone (modeled by Calista Merritt):






BUT WAIT! THERE'S MORE!
Next, we've got photoshoots! Whether you need a headshot, an engagement photo, a family portrait, or if you want to pose as Zeus hurling lightning from a cloud bank, all things are possible with perks!
Check out the options to your right. Don't see something you want? Feel free to contact me and let me know what you're thinking. By succeeding with this campaign, it means that I can take all kinds of photographs for all kind of people, reasons, and prices. 
Headshots include the basics. Hair/makeup not included, though I can (and will) touch you up as needed. I know nothing about styling men's hair. Don't even ask. Images will be retouched to your satisfaction (within reason). Bring any wardrobe changes you want. Whether you're updating your decade-old 8x10 or if it's your first time, I'll be gentle and understanding, and work with you at your own pace to get great photos.
You may notice that a milestone photo (engagement/wedding/family/pregnancy portrait, etc.) costs significantly more than a headshot. This perk is for when you want something just a much more special than a standard portrait. It will be personal, beautiful, and just what you want. I approach my portraits with the idea that they will be as beloved and treasured as, say, a painted family portrait, passed down through the generations.  While it will not be a production on the scale of a more elaborate pre-Raphaelite photo, these photos can include themes, sets, etc., within reason. Steampunk engagement photos! Dramatic, Vogue-esque new baby photos! (Is there such thing as an old baby?) This package is very unique in the fact that you will receive digital copies for reproducing these images (for your own personal use only--as wedding invitations, backup prints, etc.). This is your image for life!
Pre-Raphaelite photos are much more involved, both before and after the shoot. For these photos, I will work with you to provide and/or supplement wardrobe, props, and sets. The style, story, and location will be researched thoroughly prior to the shoot. Poses will be mapped out, storyboards drawn and locations perfected. The complexity of my initial photos increased with my experience, and I will continue that. An estimated 30-40 hours of retouching will go into each final photo. Creative decisions are ultimately my own--with this perk, I am pledging to deliver a stunning, beautiful photograph, so you're going to have to trust me. You will not receive a digital copy of the image(s), but you will have the opportunity to receive your print at whatever size you choose, up to 6', for only the additional material cost of printing.
"I want to purchase a photo perk but I can't do it before March 28th! Why are you discriminating against the date-challenged?!"
Hey, man, hey! Chill! Send me a message (contact user) and let's talk it out, yeah? I'm sure we can solve this challenge.

 NOW OFFERING PRINTS!
As requested, you can now purchase prints! Photos will be printed on velvety-soft, archival matte paper. Since my photos vary quite a bit in their dimensions, the title and blank paper will fill in for the odd sizes. Persephone, for example, will be exactly 11"x14" and will not feature a title. Please contact me if you would like the image smaller and a title added!
For odd sizes, the image will appear similarly to this:






"Why Do YOU Deserve My Money?"Great question.
I could give you a sob story about how I need a camera to make money to pay for my cats' vet bills. I could not-so-subtly work it into my campaign text by saying "I could give you a sob story about--"
Look, only you can decide if my cause is worth your money. So for my part, I'm trying to give you your money's worth; you have my gratitude if you contribute, but you deserve more than gratitude. You're helping me when I need it most, and I want to give back. The postcards are a way for me to do that on a smaller scale, while representing my work and giving you something you can use and admire. The other perks are things that I can give back, things that maybe you can't buy in a store. Who else would you turn to for a portrait of you and your six brothers as the seven dwarves? No, don't tell me, I hate competition.

"What Happens If You Don't Meet Your Goal?"

It sucks. But not for you. 
The cheapest decent DSLR on the market is about $500. If I make less than that, I will borrow/rent a camera to complete any photo perks that have been purchased. If I make more than that, I will buy the best camera & lenses that I can afford, and leftover will go toward accessories (memory cards, batteries) and future photography projects. Not a single cent of your money will be wasted. All perks will be fulfilled, all postcards shipped. Do you trust me? Then hop on my magic carpet.


Other Ways You Can Help

Got no money? Boy, can I relate. Help me out by sharing this with your friends. Share with your coworkers. Your followers.  Your parents. Your pets. Whether they're actors who need headshots or postcard enthusiasts or fans of Caravaggio and Waterhouse, tell everyone--spread the word and help me reach my goal.  It will make all of my dreams come true. Well, not the ones where I'm flying or can teleport.


"This is so long, do I have to keep reading?" Not unless you want to (or are non-US/Canada)! Here's bonus information on my pre-Raphaelite project.


More About the Pre-Raphaelite-Inspired Photos
Though I can draw decently well, I've never been able to wield a paintbrush. What do you do when your favorite artists don't work in your preferred medium? You fake it, of course.
My goal was to create rich, beautiful images that felt like paintings, but didn't use artificial brushstrokes or other such gimmicks.
One of my favorite aspects of the pre-Raphaelite style was their commitment to storytelling. Growing up, I listed greek myths and fairy tales among my favorites, and once I was old enough to understand it, I added Shakespeare. These are classic tales, recognizable by most people, young or old--but even if you don't know who the figures are, I needed the story to be told on its own.
So I needed the composition, the lighting, the subject matter, to all hearken back to the pre-Raphaelite masters. And they had to be BIG. Romeo & Juliet ended up being 3'x6' once printed, set in a gorgeous, ornate frame that weighed approximately four tons. Check out the final show here. Placards are 4"x5" for scale.
There were hits and there were misses, mostly due to time and budget constraints, and sometimes the weather. 'Persephone' ended up not including a giant chasm in the earth because, well, nobody would lend me an industrial excavator.  As a result, the story isn't obvious at first glance.
There were serendipitous moments, though, mixed with hard work; one of my professors had a stream running through her backyard, and with a bit of digging and dam-building, we had a pond perfect for 'Echo and Narcissus'. Take a peek at Narcissus' reflection and you'll see Echo's in the water as well. Nice.
In the end, after two years of research and hard work, I had 10 beautiful images that I was proud of. I'd learned to work with a hairpin budget and a mid-level camera to create photos that could be printed on a grand scale. I saw potential in every face I came across; not a single person in these photos is a professional model, they were all my fellow students.
I would love to continue this project.  Whether or not any of the pre-Raphaelite perks are purchased, if this project is funded I intend to create more of these images and will update anyone who contributed to this campaign.






***INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING*** 
Look, I don't want to profit off of the distance between us. If you're not located in the US, please calculate shipping costs for your perk and add that to your contribution. If you don't add the correct amount, you'll have the option to pay the remainder before I ship it out. 
How to calculate rates, using the USPS shipping calculator: 



1 Postcard: Select "letter" and choose weight of 1oz, and select "letter" again for the second option. 

2 Postcards: Select "letter" and choose weight of 1oz, and select "letter" again for the second option.

5 Postcards: Select "large envelope" and choose weight of 2oz, and select "rigid" on the second page. 


10 Postcards: Select "large envelope" and choose weight of 4oz, and select "rigid" and "over 1/4" thickness" on the second page. 


100 Postcards: Select "package" and choose weight of 30oz. Depending on your location, it may be cheaper to select "Priority Mail International Large Video Flat Rate priced box". 


View "First-Class International Options" for (usually) the cheapest price. You may request a different shipping method if you add the correct amount. 


PLEASE CONTACT ME BEFORE SELECTING A PHOTOSHOOT PERK IF YOU ARE NON-US/CANADA.

story:
Hello!

My name is Paris, and I'm a student/working photographer! 
I'll soon be a college graduate, with the whole world ahead of me to photograph. My current set up is a Canon Rebel XS, and although it has been faithful over the past couple of years, it's starting to age. Error upon error message is what I'm faced with on current shoots and it is time to retire her! 

I see my future being as big and bold as Annie Leibovitz, Mario Testino, Mert & Marcus, and Steven Klein. This Canon 5D Mark Three will take my photography to the next level, ultimately being the mode of transportation to my future success!

 

The Goods!

The Canon 5D mkiii runs around $3500, so with the $4000 we raise I will be able to puchase the camera body along with a lens! Any additional funds will go towards more lenses, and gear! Here is a little insight on my "grocery list"... 

  • 5D mkiii body
  • Camera bag
  • 50mm f/1.4 lens
  • 85mm f/1.8 lens

If I don't reach my entire goal, the funds will sit in an account until I have the full amount necessary to make my purchase. Not a single dime will go towards anything but camera equipment!

 - 

My heart belongs to all of you who believe in what I am doing, even those who cannot contribute financially. If all you can do is hit the "share" button, or spread the word throughout your friends while out for a cup of coffee.. I cannot express my gratitude to each and every one of you! My biggest thanks to you will be my first magazine cover, then my first cover on W magazine, and finally, the first cover on Vogue magazine. 

See you there ;)

xoxo

story:
Our Story

John Harlien didn't even flinch the second time Tulsa, Oklahoma police came for him with pepper spray canisters. As dozens of police and hired additional security assembled behind him in the dark recesses of the park, he calmly smeared Vaseline across his eyelids, down his cheeks and inside his nostrils. Another protester had told him the cream would help protect him from the burn of the spray when it almost certainly came.

Two nights before, Harlien was one of nine Occupy Tulsa protesters pepper sprayed by Tulsa police while sitting peacefully on the ground, hands zip-tied behind them, propelling Oklahoma and the Occupy protests once again into the national spotlight.

“What happened Tuesday night, with the pepper spray, well, it burned like none other,” Harlien said. “I couldn’t see anything, I had to be led to the paddy wagon. I could barely breathe, and I didn’t dare swallow or inhale through my nose. My face was a mess of drool and snot because anytime I tried to swallow or breathe through my nose, it just burned more."

Once he had been led to the police vehicle, Harlien said he was told he would be booked and allowed to wash the spray from his body and change clothes, but that never happened. In fact, he was held for 10 hours while the spray continued to burn his eyes and throat.

"Once we got to booking, it was probably an hour or more before I could open even one eye," Harlien said. "We were told when we were loaded in that once we got to booking, they’d give us something to help deal with the pepper spray. The whole 10 hours I was there, nothing was given to me. I went through a lot of pain, but the message was definitely worth it.”

The Impact

Snapshots of the American Autumn: A Portrait in Protesting is scheduled to premiere at MAINSITE Art Gallery in Norman, Oklahoma on June 9, 2012, and will be exhibited for two months. The exhibition, featuring images from Occupy Protests around the Midwest by photojournalist Kendall Brown, will include large scale portraits of protesters installed within the walls of the gallery as well as smaller-scale images wheat pasted through out Norman and the surrounding areas in the months leading up to the show's opening. In addition, the portraits and contextualizing images will be printed within their own broadsheet newspaper that will be available around Norman and at the show, providing further information about the movement.

The motivation behind the exhibition is to communicate both the collective and individual voices of the Occupy movement, both in protests taking place throughout the United States as well as happening around the world. Utilizing a photojournalism approach with a fine-art objective, Brown traveled to Occupy protest encampments throughout the heartland, collecting the images and stories of protesters in order to understand what their individual motivations were as well as the collective force that bound them together as a group.

For the project Brown was immersed in the protest, standing with the occupiers and camping alongside them in order to most fully document their, and her own, experiences.

Rather than presenting the protests in typical photojournalistic style, showing the protesters in their environment, Brown was inspired by the work of Avedon, choosing to intentionally remove the protesters from their surroundings to allow the viewer to see the protester for who they are as a human first. The resulting images are more fine art than photojournalism. As the protests have continued, many times in the mainstream media protesters were intentionally framed within their surroundings to allow the stereotypes regarding the movement to be perpetuated. Brown's images seek to rectify this and foster a conversation that crosses party lines by confronting the viewer with images that abolish those stereotypes.

How the Funds Will be Used

All of the money raised will be used to assist with the cost of producing the show, including:

- printing the floor-to-ceiling images to be hung inside of MAINSITE Art Gallery
- design and printing of Occupy newspapers that will be available to show attendees, featuring further images and reading material to contextualize the portraits
- printing and pasting of smaller-scale images throughout the area surrounding the gallery in the months leading up to the show premiere

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the project with as many people as you can!

Note about donations: Snapshots of the American Autumn: A Portrait in Protesting is being co-sponsored by the Norman Arts Council, making all donations tax deductible. To arrange for verification of your donation for tax purposes, please contact Kendall at kendallybrown@gmail.com.

story:
Outside of the Stadiums presents a collection of photographs of people, places, customs and traditions within innovative initiatives in the northeastern region of Brazil. The images show the daily life of communities outside of the context of the 2014 FIFA World Cup. This is a look at another reality in the country of soccer.

In January of 2014, in the state of Pernambuco, Brazil, our multinational team (two photographers from the US and Argentina, a community organizer from Brazil and a tech wiz from Costa Rica) visited nine communities and had creative exchanges and made new friends through the art of photography.  All-day photography workshops were given in each place.  Cameras were distributed (and donated) to students with lessons on lighting, composition, and portraiture.  Students toured their communities to photograph their own stories.  Later their images were projected on a large scale outdoors and shared.  Images were printed and certificates of course completion were distributed.  During these workshops, every student's portrait was taken with the intention of later exhibiting the portraits through the Inside Out Project.

Through photographic lenses, we were exposed to the grassroots initiatives taking place in each community.  Photography was exchanged for music, dance, fresh farm food, soccer, art, and tours in beautiful deserts and beaches. Our project, Outside of the Stadiums, celebrates these important initiatives and communities.

Outside of the Stadiums focuses on giving more attention to these communities in Pernambuco, home of the Itaipava Arena Pernambuco Stadium.   Welcome to our project and thank you for participating during this month of the World Cup.

Please consider giving to this cause at this time. 

We are raising money:

1.  To make calendars for each organization to sell and make their own funds,

2.  For the Inside Out Project : http://www.insideoutproject.net/en,

3.  Travel expenses and supplies bought during the project: (cameras, art supplies, food for the students),

4.  International photo exhibitions in Recife, Brazil, Buenos Aires, Argentina, San José, Costa Rica, and New York City, US featuring the photographs and art of and by the students.

Details about the nine communities in Pernambuco:

In the community of Coque, home of the Associação Maracatu Nação de Oxalá, children shared their musical and dance traditions.  After a full day of photography, they performed a percussive street procession which engaged the whole town.  This organization teaches boys and girls Maracatu traditions, which are an integral part of Brazilian culture and identity.

São Lourenço da Mata, one of the hosts of the 2014 FIFA World Cup, is a city located in the greater Recife metropolitan area.  

This is the city where the new stadium, 

Itaipava Arena Pernambuco,

 is found.  

During our photography work, we learned that this community largely supports themselves on found things from its sprawling garbage dump. This community may never personally see the improvements on the local economy that the World Cup is said to bring.

We met, documented and shared an afternoon of organic fruits and vegetables with the Movimiento Sim Terra (Landless Movement) Chico Mendes III. They represent political environmentalism and agragarian reform. Their fundamental objective is to have more equal distribution of the land. The Movimiento Sim Tierra/Chico Mendes III farm is run as a cooperative.  The members gave us tours of their farms, gardens, and adobe homes.  We witnessed their sustainable techniques and partook in a delicious, homegrown organic lunch.  This land, damaged through years of use as sugarcane plantations littered with pesticides and fertilizers, has been reclaimed, improved and restored by the local farmer families as sustainable and productive land.


Itamaracá is an island. There we worked in a community center for children and adults.  When we asked a school teacher what she thought about the World Cup near her city, she answered positively, yet said that the most important thing for her was peace, peace for Brazil, especially during this time of rivalry between countries.  At night, we were included in a local music festival where the famous singer, Lia de Itamaracá, performed.

Itapissuma, separated from Itamaracá by a bridge, is a fishing village close to the beach. Here we worked at an elementary school with children and they took us to meet the local fishermen.  We witnessed a religious festival called Festa de São Gonçalo, where a saint was carried from the sea by boat and paraded through the town.  The connection that this community to the sea is very strong.  

In Belo Jardim, in the community of Cohabi III, we worked with an organization called Lata Organica. Founded in 2010, children learn to play percussion instruments made out of recycled goods and play as a troupe in other parts of Brazil. Playing local rhythms like Samba-reggae and Maracatu, they performed for us after a day of taking photographs of their places, peoples and spaces.

Fundação Terra: Samba de Coco Malhada was founded in 2010.  This group seeks to promote cultural activities and an extended school day for 25 children and adolescents. Their project seeks to create social inclusion through the arts. They showed us their surrounding arid neighborhood and shared locally grown cashew fruits.


In Catimbau, we worked with the National Park to recruit participants for the workshops. We worked at a school where we gathered a combination of teenagers and park guides. The guides provided a day-long tour of the park.  During this tour, we donated an infrared camera and it was installed under a rocky precipice to monitor local wildlife populations.  We also visited a village of artisans who carve wooden sculptures from recycled wood.

Back in the city of Recife, we worked with the Centro de Assistência Integral Novo Rebanho. Novo Rebanho promotes social inclusion through education for all ages. They have a soccer team that was excited to talk about the World Cup being in their home city.
